German: <haha>Natürlich würdest du!

English: <pumped>Just try and trample us here, I reckon!
French: <pumped>Ils devraient essayer de nous piétiner ici, pour voir !
Chinese (Simplified): <pumped>如果有人胆敢在这儿欺负人！
Japanese: <pumped>できるものなら、踏みつけてみなよ！
German: <pumped>Soll doch mal einer versuchen, hier über uns drüber zu trampeln!

English: <angry>We’ll give them what for!þ
French: <angry>On leur rendrait la monnaie de leur pièce !
German: <angry>Der wird uns aber kennenlernen!

English: <proud>That’s mateship, that is.þ
French: <proud>C'est ça, l'amitié.
German: <proud>Wir halten zusammen.

English: You can’t always trust people, <PlayerName>, but you can always trust them to be themselves.þþ
French: On ne peut pas toujours faire confiance aux gens, <PlayerName>, mais on peut toujours leur faire confiance d'être eux-mêmes.
Chinese (Simplified): 不能总是信任别人，<PlayerName>，但你可以始终相信人们会做自己。
Japanese: <PlayerName>、いつでも人を信じるわけにはいかないが、人はみんな真の自分であることは信じていい。
Korean: <PlayerName>님, 사람을 항상 믿을 수는 없지만, 그 사람이 누구인지는 항상 믿을 수 있습니다.þþ
Portuguese: Você nem sempre pode confiar nas pessoas, <PlayerName>, mas você sempre pode confiar que elas sejam elas mesmas.
German: Du kannst den Leuten nicht immer trauen, <PlayerName>, aber du kannst immer sicher sein, ///dass sie sie selbst sind.

English: As long as you keep that in mind, nothing will surprise you, I reckon.þ
French: Tant que tu gardes cela à l'esprit, tu n'auras jamais de surprise, à mon avis.
Chinese (Simplified): 只要牢记这一点，没有什么会让你感到惊讶。
Japanese: それを念頭に置いておけば、驚かされることはないだろう。
Korean: 이 점을 염두에 두기만 한다면 놀랄 일은 없을 것입니다.þ
Portuguese: Desde que você se lembre disso, nada irá surpreender você, eu acho.
German: Solange du das nicht vergisst, dürfte dich nichts mehr überraschen, schätze ich.

English: Anyway, I like you <petName>, but I’ve got work to do!þ
French: Enfin, je t'aime bien <petName>, mais j'ai du travail !
Chinese (Simplified): 我喜欢你，<petName>，但我有事要忙！
Japanese: とにかく、<petName>のことは好きなんだけど今は仕事がある！
Korean: 어쨌든 난 당신이 <petName>인 걸 좋아하지만 할 일이 있어요!þ
Portuguese: Enfim. Eu gosto de você, <petName>, mas tenho trabalho a fazer!
German: Wie dem auch sei. Ich mag dich, <petName>, aber ich habe zu tun!

English: <proud>I worked hard to get where I am, I did.
French: <proud>J'ai travaillé dur pour en arriver là où je suis.
Chinese (Simplified): <proud>我付出了巨大的努力才取得今天的成就。
Japanese: <proud>熱心に働いて、今の私になったんだ。
Korean: <proud>나는 지금의 위치에 도달하기 위해 열심히 일했습니다.
Portuguese: <proud>Eu trabalhei bastante para chegar onde estou, sim.
German: <proud>Ich habe hart gearbeitet, um dorthin zu kommen, wo ich jetzt bin. Oh ja, das habe ich.

English: <yes>There was always someone there telling me I couldn’t do it.þ
French: <yes>Il y avait toujours quelqu'un pour me dire que je n'y arriverai pas.
Japanese: <yes>「君には無理だ」と言う人は常にいた。
Korean: <yes>내가 하면 안 된다고 말하는 사람이 늘 있었어요.þ
Portuguese: <yes>Sempre havia alguém me dizendo que eu não conseguiria.
German: <yes>Irgendwer versuchte immer, mir einzureden, ich würde das nicht schaffen.

English: I didn’t have a head for business, they says.
French: On me disait que je n'avais pas le sens des affaires.
Chinese (Simplified): 他们说我没有商业头脑。
Japanese: 「ビジネスの才能はないんだ」などとね。
Korean: 나는 사업에 대한 머리가 없었다고 그들은 말합니다.
Portuguese: Eu não tinha uma habilidade para os negócios, diziam eles.
German: Ich hätte keinen Geschäftssinn, sagten sie.

English: <no>My cooking was trash, they says, blah blah blah blah.þ
French: <no>Ma cuisine était mauvaise, qu'ils disaient, bla bla bla bla.
Japanese: <no>たとえば、私の料理はゴミだなんてことも言われたよ。
Portuguese: <no>Minha culinária era uma porcaria, diziam eles, blá, blá, blá.
German: <no>Ich könne nicht kochen, sagten sie. Bla-bla-bla …

English: <angry>I’d had just about enough of it, so I says, stuff that, and stuff you too!þ
French: <angry>J'en ai eu assez, alors j'ai dit, je m'en fiche, et je me fiche de vous aussi !
Chinese (Simplified): <angry>听得我心烦，我直接回，去你们的！
Japanese: <angry>そんなことは聞き飽きたから、自分のことをやれよと言っておいた！
Korean: <angry>내가 충분히 먹었으니 그걸로 채우고 너도 채우라고!þ
Portuguese: <angry>Eu me cansei disso, eu dizia. Dane-se isso e dane-se você também!
German: <angry>Irgendwann hatte ich die Schnauze voll und sagte: ///Lasst mich doch einfach in Ruhe!

English: <proud>Sooner or later you’ve got to just ignore the whingers and take charge of yourself.þ
French: <proud>Tôt ou tard, il faut ignorer les grincheux et t'occuper de toi.
Chinese (Simplified): <proud>人迟早得学会忽视外界的闲言碎语，把握住自己的内心。
Japanese: <proud>いずれにせよ、愚痴は無視して自分のことは自分で責任を持たなきゃならない。
Korean: <proud>조만간 징징거리는 소리를 무시하고 스스로 책임을 져야 합니다.þ
Portuguese: <proud>Cedo ou tarde, você precisa apenas ignorar os chatos e tomar conta de si.
German: <proud>Früher oder später musst du die ///Meckerköppe///Nörgelheinis einfach ignorieren und dein Leben selbst in die Hand nehmen.

English: You should listen, <PlayerName>, I bloody wish I did sooner!þ
French: Tu devrais écouter, <PlayerName>, j'aurais dû le faire plus tôt !
Chinese (Simplified): 记住这句话，<PlayerName>。真希望我能早点做到！
Japanese: <PlayerName>には行っておきたいんだけど、もっと早く行動に移せればなと思っているよ！
Portuguese: Você deve ouvir, <PlayerName>. Eu queria ter ouvido isso antes!
German: Du solltest gut zuhören, <PlayerName>. Ich wünschte, ich hätte es früher getan!

English: You’re a good egg, <PlayerName>, I mean that.þ
French: Tu es une bonne personne, <PlayerName>, je suis honnête.
Japanese: つまり、<PlayerName>はいい人だと言いたかったんだ。
Korean: 넌 정말 좋은 사람이야, <PlayerName>, 내 말은.þ
Portuguese: Você é uma boa pessoa, <PlayerName>. Falo sério.
German: Du bist schwer in Ordnung, <PlayerName>, das meine ich wirklich ernst.

English: <shy>I appreciate you taking the time to listen to me natter on.þ
French: <shy>J'apprécie que tu prennes le temps de m'écouter bavarder.
Japanese: <shy>おしゃべりを聞いてくれてありがとう。
Portuguese: <shy>Eu gosto que você separou um tempo para me ouvir reclamar.
German: <shy>Ich danke dir, dass du dir Zeit genommen und dir mein Geschwätz angehört hast.

English: <haha>Most times I’d be nattering regardless, but it’s nice to have somebody listen!þ
French: <haha>La plupart du temps, je bavarde de toute façon, mais c'est bien d'avoir quelqu'un qui écoute !
Chinese (Simplified): <haha>大多数时候，无论如何我都会唠叨，但有人愿意倾听真是太好了！
Japanese: <haha>私は基本的におしゃべりだけど、聞いてくれる人がいるというのはありがたいよ。
Korean: <하하>대부분의 나는 상관없이 수다를 떨었지만 누군가 들어준다는 것은 좋은 일이다!þ
Portuguese: <haha>Na maioria das vezes, eu reclamaria do mesmo jeito, mas é legal ter alguém para ouvir.
German: <haha>Meistens schwatze ich auch so vor mich hin, aber es ist immer nett, wenn jemand zuhört.

English: You let me know if you need anything, <petName>.þ
French: Dis-le-moi si tu as besoin de quelque chose, <petName>.
Japanese: <petName>は、必要なものがあったら相談してくれる。
Portuguese: Me diga se precisar de alguma coisa, <petName>.
German: Sag mir Bescheid, wenn du etwas brauchst, <petName>.

English: You ever wonder about all that junk buried beneath the surface?þ
French: Tu as déjà pensé à toutes les choses enfouies sous la surface ?
Chinese (Simplified): 你有好奇过埋在地下的那些垃圾吗？
Japanese: 地面の下に埋もれているガラクタについて気になったことはあるかい？
Korean: 표면 아래에 묻혀 있는 모든 쓰레기에 대해 궁금한 적이 있습니까?þ
Portuguese: Você pensa sobre todo aquele lixo enterrado abaixo da superfície?
German: Hast du dich jemals gefragt, was der ganze Plunder ist, der da unter der Oberfläche vergraben liegt?

English: You reckon someone left it there or what?þ
French: Tu penses que quelqu'un les a laissées là ou quoi ?
Chinese (Simplified): 是谁留下的，还是怎么回事？
Japanese: 誰かがほったらかしていったんだろうか？
Portuguese: Você acha que alguém deixou lá ou o quê?
German: Denkst du, jemand hat das Zeug zurückgelassen, oder was?

English: I like to think it was the <animalName>. Nah, hear me out!þ
French: J'aime penser que c'était <animalName>. Non, écoute !
Chinese (Simplified): 我觉得是<animalName>干的，先听我说完！
Japanese: 私は<animalName>の仕業だと思っている。いや、話を聞いておくれ！
Korean: <animalName>이었던 것 같아요. 아니, 내 말 좀 들어봐!þ
Portuguese: Gosto de pensar que foi <animalName>. Não, me escute!
German: Ich glaube ja, dass es ///der <animalName> war. Nein, warte, hör mir zu!

English: They had all these fancy machines, yeah? All these whirring and buzzing things and what-have-you.þ
French: Ils avaient toutes ces machines sophistiquées, ok ? Toutes ces choses qui ronronnent et bourdonnent, et tout.
Chinese (Simplified): 它们是有这些花哨的机器，对吧？这些嗡嗡作响的东西等等。
Japanese: あいつらがあのすごい機械を持っていたってわけさ。あのブンブン音を立てるやつを。
Korean: 그 사람들은 이런 멋진 기계들을 다 갖고 있었죠, 그렇죠? 이 모든 윙윙거리고 윙윙거리는 것들과 당신이 갖고 있는 것이 무엇인지.þ
Portuguese: Eles tinham todas aquelas máquinas extravagantes, né? Todas aquelas coisas zumbindo e zunindo etc.
German: Die hatten doch all diese schicken Maschinen, richtig? All diese surrenden und brummenden ///Dingsdas und was weiß ich noch alles.

English: Well, they’ve got them all going full bull at all hours, right?þ
French: Eh bien, elles fonctionnent à plein régime à toute heure, pas vrai ?
Chinese (Simplified): 这些机器开足马力全天候运转，合理吧？
Japanese: あいつらはいつだって、全力で騒いでいる。
Korean: 글쎄, 그들은 항상 모든 시간을 완전하게 진행하고 있습니다. 그렇죠?þ
Portuguese: Bom, eles tinham tudo funcionando com força total a todo o momento, né?
German: Die liefen zu jeder Tages- und Nachtzeit auf vollen Touren, richtig?

English: Well, <animalName> bossman is cranky now. The head <animalName> or whatever, Top Dog.þ
French: Eh bien, le boss <animalName> est grincheux maintenant. Le <animalName> principal ou je ne sais pas, le grand manitou.
Chinese (Simplified): 结果弄得<animalName>的头儿心里特别烦躁。<animalName>首领，领头的，之类的。
Japanese: <animalName>のボスは不機嫌そうでしょ。ヘッド<animalName>？トップドッグ？何と呼べばいいんだっけ。
Korean: 글쎄요, <animalName> 상사가 지금 짜증을 내는군요. <animalName> 머리든 뭐든, Top Dog.þ
Portuguese: Bom, o chefe <animalName> está rabugento agora. O chefe <animalName> ou sei lá o quê, líder.
German: Naja, der <animalName>-Boss kommt ganz mies drauf. Der <animalName>-///Rudelführer oder wie auch immer er bezeichnet wird. Der ///Obermufti halt.

English: He can’t get to sleep, see, on account of all the ruckus.þ
French: Il ne peut pas dormir, tu vois, à cause de tout ce bruit.
Chinese (Simplified): 因为噪音太大，他睡不着觉。
Japanese: 大きな音のせいで眠れやしない。
Korean: 그는 온갖 소란 때문에 잠을 잘 수 없습니다.þ
Portuguese: Ele não consegue dormir, sabe, por causa de todo o tumulto.
German: Er kann nämlich nicht schlafen, weißt du, wegen dem ganzen Gelärme.

English: So one day he says, “Oi, youse!”, he says, “Pack that in, the lot of you!”þ
French: Donc, un jour, il dit « Hé, vous là ! », qu'il dit, « Remballez tout ça, vous autres ! »
Chinese (Simplified): 终于有一天，他忍不住说：“喂，你们听好了！全都消停点儿！”
Japanese: ある日「おまえら！それを仕舞え！」と怒鳴りつけたってわけ。
Korean: 그래서 어느 날 그는 “아, 너네!”라고 말하고는 “그걸 담아, 많은 분들!”이라고 말합니다.þ
Portuguese: Então um dia ele diz: “Ei, vocês!”. Ele diz: “Vocês, enterrem tudo!”
German: Und so sagt er eines Tages: „He, ihr da! Ihr alle, räumt das Zeug da weg!“

English: So they do, too.
French: Et ils le font.
Japanese: 他の連中も同意したんだろう。
German: Und das tun sie.

English: They bury heaps of it, they do. So’s they can focus on all the regular important <animalName> stuff.þ
French: Ils enterrent plein de choses. Donc ils peuvent se concentrer sur des trucs de <animalName> importants.
Chinese (Simplified): 他们埋掉了很多东西，以便专注于重要的<animalName>日常活动。
Japanese: そして大量のガラクタを埋めてしまい、<animalName>が普通やることに集中できるようになったということ。
Korean: 그들은 그것의 더미를 묻습니다. 그래서 그들은 모든 중요한 <animalName> 항목에 집중할 수 있습니다.þ
Portuguese: Eles enterram pilhas disso, sim. Então podem focar em todo a questão importa e comum de <animalName>.
German: Sie vergraben ganze Haufen davon. Und so können sie sich um die üblichen wichtigen <animalName>-Angelegenheiten kümmern.

English: Like, um, burying and sniffing and running and all that malarky.þ
French: Genre, euh, enterrer et renifler et toutes ces choses.
Chinese (Simplified): 比如，埋东西、闻气味、奔跑等乱七八糟的事情。
Japanese: ものを埋めたり、匂いを嗅いだり、走り回ったりという他愛のないことをね。
Korean: 예를 들어, 땅을 묻고, 냄새를 맡고, 달리고, 그 모든 것들이 엉망입니다.þ
Portuguese: Tipo, enterrar, cheirar, correr e toda aquela bobagem.
German: Also um das Vergraben und Rumschnüffeln und Rumrennen und den ganzen Quatsch.

English: <yes>That’s my theory anyway.þ
French: <yes>Enfin, c'est ma théorie.
German: <yes>Das ist jedenfalls meine Theorie.

English: <no>I’d like to say I was great at rustling up tucker straight from the word Go, but that wouldn’t be true.þ
French: <no>J'aimerais dire que j'étais douée pour préparer des repas dès le début, mais ça serait mentir.
Chinese (Simplified): <no>其实我想夸自己一开始就擅长烹饪，但并非属实。
Japanese: <no>私は昔から食事を素早く用意するのが得意だったと言いたいところだが、実はそうではないんだ。
Korean: <no>나는 바둑이라는 단어부터 바로 터커를 바스락거리는 데 능숙하다고 말하고 싶지만 그것은 사실이 아닙니다.þ
Portuguese: <no>Eu gostaria de dizer que eu era ótima em arranjar comida imediatamente, mas isso não seria verdade.
German: <no>Ich würde gern behaupten, ich hätte von Anfang an perfektes Essen zubereiten können, aber das wäre leider nicht die Wahrheit.

English: <shy>Nah mate, I burned more than a few <itemName> to get here, I did.þ
French: <shy>Non mon pote, j'ai brûlé pas mal de <itemName> pour en arriver là, c'est vrai.
Chinese (Simplified): <shy>朋友，我烧焦过不少<itemName>才练就现在的厨艺。
Japanese: <shy>ここまで来るのに、<itemName>をいくつも燃やしたよ。
Korean: <shy>아니 친구, 여기까지 오기 위해 <itemName>을 몇 개 이상 태웠어요.þ
Portuguese: <shy>Não, colega. Eu queimei mais do que alguns <itemName> para chegar aqui, sim.
German: <shy>Nee Kumpel, ich habe mehr als nur ///ein paar <itemName> anbrennen lassen, bis ich soweit war.

English: <pumped>Ate every single one of them too! Builds character.þ
French: <pumped>Et j'ai tout mangé ! Ça forge le caractère.
Chinese (Simplified): <pumped>而且每一份我都吃了！这么做可以锻炼性格。
Japanese: <pumped>全部食べたよ！そうして人格が形成された。
Portuguese: <pumped>Também comi todos eles. Constrói o caráter.
German: <pumped>Hab aber jede einzelne Mahlzeit aufgegessen! Das formt den Charakter.

English: Only way to learn, I reckon. þ
French: C'est la seule façon d'apprendre, à mon avis.
Japanese: それが唯一の学習方法だったよ。
Portuguese: É a única maneira de aprender, eu acho.
German: Das ist die einzige Art, etwas zu lernen, denke ich.

English: <pumped>Not just pies either!
French: <pumped>Et ce n'était pas seulement des tartes !
Japanese: <pumped>パイに限った話ではないよ！
German: <pumped>Nicht nur Pasteten!

English: <shy>Nah, I burnt a salad first time I tried it!þ
French: <shy>Non, j'ai brûlé une salade la première fois que j'ai essayé !
Japanese: <shy>サラダだって、最初に試したときは燃やしたものさ！
Portuguese: <shy>Não, eu queimei uma salada da primeira vez que comi!
German: <shy>Beim ersten Mal ist mir sogar ein Salat angebrannt!

English: <glee>WOW!
French: <glee>HOUA !
Indonesian: WOW!
German: <glee>WOW!

English: Look at all these really, really cute bugs!
French: Regarde ces insectes vraiment, vraiment mignons !
Japanese: なんてかわいい虫なんだ！
Korean: 이 정말 정말 귀여운 벌레들을 보세요!
Portuguese: Olha para esses insetos muito, muito fofinhos!
German: Sieh dir nur diese total niedlichen kleinen Krabbeltiere an!

English: Can I buy them for <$>?
French: Est-ce que je peux les acheter pour <$> ?
Chinese (Simplified): 我出 <$> 跟你买可以吗？
German: Kann ich sie für <$> kaufen?

English: Sell!
French: Vendu !
German: Verkauft!

English: No thanks
French: Non, merci
Indonesian: Tidak, terima kasih.
German: Nein, danke.

English: Thanks <PlayerName>!
French: Merci <PlayerName> !
Indonesian: Terima kasih, <PlayerName>.
German: Danke, <PlayerName>!

English: <no>Oh...
French: <no>Oh...
Indonesian: Oh...
German: <no>Oh …

English: <thinking>Hmmm.
French: <thinking>Hum.
Indonesian: <thinking>Hmmm…
German: <thinking>Hmmm.

English: Some great produce here, <PlayerName>.
French: Il y a de bons produits là, <PlayerName>.
Japanese: 素晴らしい産物があるよ、<PlayerName>。
German: Das sind wirklich tolle Erzeugnisse, <PlayerName>.

English: How does <$> sound?
French: Que dirais-tu de <$> ?
German: Wie klingen <$>?

English: Sell!
French: Vendu !
German: Verkauft!

English: No thanks
French: Non, merci
Indonesian: Tidak, terima kasih.
German: Nein, danke.

English: Pleasure doing business, <PlayerName>!
French: C'est un plaisir de faire affaire avec toi, <PlayerName> !
German: Immer ein Vergnügen, mit dir Geschäfte zu machen, <PlayerName>!

English: All right... Lets see...
French: Très bien... Voyons voir...
German: OK … Sehen wir mal …

English: It seems these items aren't worth anything, but I can still take them off your hands if you don't want them?
French: On dirait que ces objets ne valent pas grand-chose, mais je peux quand même t'en débarrasser si tu ne les veux pas ?
Chinese (Simplified): 这些物品一文不值，但如果你不想要了，不如给我？
Japanese: このアイテムには価値がないようだけど、いらないようなら受け取ることはできるよ。
Korean: 이 물건들은 아무 가치도 없는 것 같지만, 원치 않으시면 제가 당신 손에서 떼어드릴 수도 있나요?
Portuguese: Parece que esses itens não valem nada, mas ainda posso ficar com eles se você não quiser?
German: Diese Gegenstände haben offenbar keinerlei Wert. Ich kann sie dir aber abnehmen, wenn du sie nicht mehr haben möchtest.

English: Yes, I dont want them.
French: Oui, je n'en veux pas.
Indonesian: Ya, aku tidak menginginkannya.
German: Ja, ich möchte sie nicht mehr.

English: I'll have them back thanks.
French: Je vais les reprendre, merci.
Japanese: じゃあ、返してもらうね。どうも。
Indonesian: Aku akan mengambilnya kembali, terima kasih.
German: Ich nehme sie zurück, danke.

English: Righto, mate.
French: D'ac, mon pote.
Indonesian: Baiklah, kawan.
German: Alles klar, Kumpel.

English: Cheers.
French: Merci.
Indonesian: Salut, .
German: Danke.

English: That's fine, please return if you wish to sell anything else.
French: Pas de problème, reviens me voir si tu veux vendre autre chose.
Japanese: わかった。他のものを売りたいなら、またおいで。
Korean: 괜찮습니다. 다른 제품을 판매하고 싶으시면 반품해 주세요.
Portuguese: Tudo bem. Devolva se você quiser vender outra coisa.
German: Gerne. Komm einfach wieder, wenn du etwas anderes verkaufen möchtest.

English: G’day.
French: Salut.
Russian: Привет.
Chinese (Traditional): 你好。
Thai: สวัสดี
Indonesian: Hai.
Italian: Ciao.
Turkish: Selam.
German: Hallo!

English: Me name’s <myName>.
French: J'm'appelle <myName>.
Russian: Меня зовут <myName>.
Chinese (Traditional): 我的名字是<myName>。
Thai: ฉันชื่อ <myName>
Indonesian: Namaku <myName>.
Italian: Mi chiamo <myName>.
Turkish: Ben <myName>.
German: Ich heiße <myName>.

English: I’m <NPCName>’s little brother!
French: Je suis le petit frère de <NPCName> !
Russian: Я младший брат <NPCName>!
Chinese (Traditional): 我是<NPCName>的弟弟！
Thai: ฉันเป็นน้องชายของ <NPCName>
Indonesian: Aku adik laki-laki <NPCName>!
Italian: Sono il fratello minore di <NPCName>!
Portuguese: Eu sou o irmão mais novo de <NPCName>!
Turkish: <NPCName>'un küçük kardeşiyim!
German: Ich bin <NPCName>s kleiner Bruder!

English: Speaking of <NPCName>, he mentioned that the <itemName> are migrating around this time of the year.
French: À propos de <NPCName>, il a dit que les <itemName> migrent à cette période de l'année.
Russian: Что касается <NPCName>, он упоминал, что <itemName> мигрируют в это время года.
Chinese (Simplified): 说到<NPCName>，他提过<itemName>每年这个时候都会迁徙。
Japanese: そういえば<NPCName>が、今年はこの時期に<itemName>が回遊すると言っていた。
Korean: <NPCName> 말이 나와서 말인데, <itemName> 이동 시기가 매년 이맘때쯤이라고 하더라.
Chinese (Traditional): 說到<NPCName>，他提到<itemName>在每年這個時候都會遷徙。
Thai: คือว่า <NPCName> เล่าให้ฉันฟังว่า <itemName> จะย้ายถิ่นในช่วงนี้ของปี
Indonesian: Omong-omong soal <NPCName>, dia sempat berkata bahwa <itemName> bermigrasi pada musim ini.
Italian: Parlando di <NPCName>, ha menzionato il fatto che i <itemName> migrano durante questo periodo dell'anno.
Spanish (Latin Americas): Ya que hablamos de <NPCName>, mencionó que las <itemName> están en plena migración en esta época del año.
Portuguese: Falando em <NPCName>, ele disse que <itemName> estão migrando nesta época do ano.
Turkish: <NPCName> yılın bu zamanlarında <itemName> göçü olduğundan bahsetmişti.
German: Wo wir gerade von <NPCName> sprechen, er meinte, dass die <itemName> in dieser Jahreszeit wandern.

English: That means today is one of the only days you’ll find them out during the whole day.
French: Cela veut dire qu'aujourd'hui est l'un des seuls jours où tu pourras les trouver en pleine journée.
Russian: Значит, сегодня один из немногих дней, когда их можно обнаружить в течение всего дня.
Chinese (Simplified): 也就是说，今天一整天都能看到它们的身影，像这样的日子不多。
Japanese: つまり、今日は一日中探し回れる貴重な日ってことだ。
Korean: 그 말인즉슨, 하루 종일 녀석들을 만날 수 있는 흔치 않은 날 중 하나가 바로 오늘이라는 거지.
Chinese (Traditional): 這表示今天是每年少數幾天之一，你可以整天看到牠們出來活動。
Thai: ซึ่งเท่ากับว่าวันนี้จะเป็นหนึ่งในไม่กี่วันที่ปลาพวกนี้จะปรากฏตัวให้เห็นตลอดทั้งวัน
Indonesian: Itu berarti sekarang adalah salah satu hari tertentu saat kita bisa melihat mereka sepanjang hari.
Italian: Ciò significa che oggi è uno dei pochi giorni in cui potrai trovarli per l'intera giornata.
Spanish (Latin Americas): Hoy es uno de los pocos momentos en que las verás por allí durante todo el día.
Portuguese: Isso significa que hoje é um dos poucos dias que você poderá encontrá-los por aí durante todo o dia.
Turkish: Yani bugün, tüm gün boyunca dışarıda onları görebileceğim nadir günlerden biri.
German: Heute ist also einer der wenigen Tage, an denen sie den ganzen Tag draußen sind.

English: <haha>As soon as he mentioned that, I booked me ticket!
French: <haha>Dès qu'il m'en a parlé, j'ai réservé mon billet !
Russian: <haha>Как только он об этом упомянул, я забронировал билет!
Chinese (Simplified): <haha>他话音刚落，我就立马订了票！
Japanese: <haha>それを聞いた瞬間、チケットを予約したよ！
Chinese (Traditional): <haha>他一提到這件事，我馬上就訂了票！
Thai: <haha>พอเขาเล่าจบ ฉันก็รีบจองตั๋วมาเลย!
Indonesian: <haha>Setelah dia bilang begitu, aku pun langsung memesan tiket!
Italian: <haha>Non appena me l'ha detto, ho prenotato il biglietto!
Portuguese: <haha>Quando escutei ele dizer isso, reservei logo minha passagem!
Turkish: <haha>Bundan bana bahsettiği anda biletimi rezerve ettim!
German: <haha>Nachdem er das gesagt hat, habe ich sofort mein Ticket gebucht!

English: These conditions are PERFECT for a <FishingComp>.
French: Ces conditions sont PARFAITES pour un <FishingComp>.
Russian: Это ИДЕАЛЬНЫЕ условия для <FishingComp>.
Chinese (Simplified): 这里的环境非常适合举办<FishingComp>。
Chinese (Traditional): 這些條件對<FishingComp>來說很完美。
Thai: แบบนี้แหละที่เหมาะสำหรับจัด <FishingComp> สุดๆ
Indonesian: Kondisi ini SEMPURNA untuk <FishingComp>.
Italian: Queste condizioni sono PERFETTE per una <FishingComp>.
Spanish (Latin Americas): Las condiciones son IDEALES para una <FishingComp>.
Portuguese: As condições são PERFEITAS para uma <FishingComp>.
Turkish: Koşullar <FishingComp> için MÜKEMMEL.
German: Diese Bedingungen sind PERFEKT für einen <FishingComp>.

English: I had a dream about you last night.þ
Oh, that’s nice.þ
Actually, it was kind of a nightmare…
Japanese: 実は、あまりいい夢じゃなくて…
Spanish (Latin Americas): En realidad, fue como una pesadilla…

English: Stay away from the water this afternoon.þ
Japanese: 午後は水に近づかないように。

English: Why is that?þ
Just a feeling.þ
You know what?þ
What?þ
Oh, that’s tomorrow. Nevermind.þ
Japanese: ああ、それは明日だった。気にしないで。
Spanish (Latin Americas): Ah, eso es mañana. No importa.

English: I know you’re going to have a good day.þ
Korean: 나는 당신이 좋은 하루를 보낼 것이라는 것을 알고 있습니다.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Sé que tendrás un buen día.

English: How do you know?þ
Just do, y’know?þ
Something feels off this morning.þ
Japanese: 今朝、何か悪いことが起きる気がした。
Korean: 오늘 아침에는 뭔가 기분이 좋지 않습니다.þ

English: Like what?þ
I feel like I’ve done this already?þ
Japanese: こんな気持ち、初めてじゃない気がする。
Korean: 내가 이미 이 일을 한 것 같은 느낌이 들죠?þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Siento que ya he hecho esto.

English: I heard that voice again.þ
Japanese: またあの声が聞こえる。

English: What voice?þ
Kept me up all night…þþ
Spanish (Latin Americas): No me deja dormir de noche…

English: Clover?þ
The rain blurs my vision.þ
Japanese: 雨のせいでよく見えない。
Spanish (Latin Americas): La lluvia me nubla la vista.

English: Your eyes are blurry?þ
Japanese: 視界がぼやけているの？

English: I can’t see tomorrow anymore…þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Ya no puedo ver el mañana…

English: I know why it’s raining today.þ
Japanese: 今日が雨の理由を知っているよ。
Spanish (Latin Americas): Sé por qué está lloviendo hoy.

English: You do?þ
Yeah, it’s my fault. Sorry.þ
Japanese: 私のせいなんだ、ごめん。
Spanish (Latin Americas): Sí, es mi culpa. Lo siento.

English: Your dad sounds like a real renegade.þ
Japanese: 君のお父さんは変わり者だったようだね。
Spanish (Latin Americas): Tu papá suena como un auténtico renegado.

English: He kinda was, I tell you what!þ
Japanese: そうとも呼べる、だけど言わせて！

English: He visualised where he wanted to be and just actualised!þ
Japanese: 彼は自分がどうありたいかを思い描き、それを実現した！
Korean: 그는 자신이 원하는 곳을 시각화하고 실현했습니다!þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Visualizó dónde quería estar y lo hizo realidad.

English: I don’t know about that, but he sure was brave.
Japanese: それはわからないけど、勇敢だったのは確かだね。
Spanish (Latin Americas): No sé nada de eso, pero era muy valiente.

English: What did you used to do? Before you came here, I mean.þ
Japanese: この島に来る前は何をしていたの？
Korean: 당신은 무엇을 했나요? 여기 오기 전에 말이야.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): ¿A qué te dedicabas? Es decir, antes de venir aquí.

English: Not a lot, to be honest. I suppose I got stuck.þ
Japanese: 大したことはしていないよ、正直行き詰っていた。
Korean: 솔직히 말해서 많지는 않습니다. 아무래도 내가 막힌 것 같아.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): No mucho, honestamente. Supongo que me estanqué.

English: Yeah. I think we all kinda did? þ
Japanese: ああ、誰もがそう感じただろうね。
Korean: 응. 우리 모두 그런 것 같아요? þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Sí. Creo que a todos nos pasó.

English: Well, not anymore. I’m getting stuck in now, I’ll tell you what!
Japanese: まあ、状況は変わったよ。ここの生活が気に入っているんだ！
Korean: 글쎄, 더 이상은 아니다. 나는 지금 막혔습니다. 무엇을 말해 줄 것입니다!

English: I was thinking. How did you know where to find <IslandName>?þ
Japanese: 気になっていたんだけど、どうやって<IslandName>の場所がわかるの？
Korean: 나는 생각하고 있었다. <IslandName>이(가) 어디에 있는지 어떻게 알았나요?þ

English: I grew up here! I’d find it with my eyes closed, I’ll tell you what!þ
Japanese: 私はここで育ったからね！目を閉じてでも見つけることができるよ！
Korean: 나는 여기서 자랐다! 눈을 감고도 찾을 수 있어요. 알려드릴게요!þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Crecí aquí. La encontraría con los ojos cerrados, te lo aseguro.

English: Yeah… but didn’t everything shift? Isn’t this a different place?þ
Japanese: うん...だけど、全てが変わったんじゃ？今は違う場所でしょ？
Korean: 응... 그런데 모든 게 바뀌지 않았어? 여기 다른 곳 아닌가요?þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Sí… ¿pero no ha cambiado todo? ¿No es un lugar diferente?

English: Mate, just because I couldn’t find it on a map doesn’t mean I couldn’t find it. I mean, you know where your legs are even though they’re always moving, right?þ
Japanese: 地図に載っていないからといって、見つけられないわけじゃないよ。自分の足がどこにあるかなんて、いつも動いていてもわかるものでしょう？
Korean: 친구, 지도에서 찾을 수 없다고 해서 찾을 수 없다는 뜻은 아닙니다. 내 말은, 다리가 항상 움직이더라도 다리가 어디에 있는지 알고 있다는 거죠?þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Compa, que no haya podido ubicarla en el mapa no significa que no pudiera hallarla. Tú sabes dónde tienes las piernas aun si siempre se están moviendo, ¿no?

English: I guess so…. most of the time.þ
Japanese: まあ....たいていの場合はね。

English: Hey, could I borrow some of those shiny discs?þ
Japanese: ねえ、その光るディスクを貸してくれない？
Korean: 저기, 저 반짝이는 디스크 좀 빌릴 수 있을까요?þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Oye, ¿me prestas uno de esos discos brillantes?

English: Do you think you can access their secrets?þ
Korean: 그들의 비밀에 접근할 수 있다고 생각하시나요?þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): ¿Crees que puedes acceder a sus secretos?

English: Totally. Accessorize for days, y’know?þ
Korean: 완전히. 며칠 동안 액세서리를 해보세요. 아시죠?þ

English: That is incredible! We shall compare results!þ
I look forward to it!þ
Do your dreams ever come true?þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): ¿Alguna vez tus sueños se hacen realidad?

English: I do not dream.þ
That sounds sad, y’know?þ
I have nothing to compare it to.þ
Well I do, and, that’s sad, y’know?þ
Korean: 그렇죠, 그리고 그건 슬픈 일이군요. 알죠?þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Pues yo sí, y es triste, ¿sabes?

English: I had this one dream, about an electric pleep.þ
Korean: 나는 전기 울림에 관한 꿈을 꾸었습니다.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Una vez tuve un sueño, era sobre un ornitorrinco eléctrico.

English: What a novel idea.þ
You were in it! That’s what you said!þ
Korean: 당신은 그 안에 있었다! 그게 당신이 말한 것입니다!þ

English: What transpired after that?þ
I don’t know. I just woke up, y’know?þ
You remind me of a Bush Devil.þ
Korean: 당신은 나에게 부시 악마를 생각나게 합니다.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Me recuerdas a un demonio de los arbustos.

English: How’s that?þ
You got straight fire in your soul, y’know?þ
Korean: 당신의 영혼에는 곧바로 불이 붙었습니다. 아시죠?þ

English: I wish! Those critters are unreal!þ
Do you think those Thunder Eggs after a storm are alive?þ
Korean: 폭풍우가 몰아친 후의 천둥 알이 살아 있다고 생각하시나요?þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): ¿Crees que esos huevos de trueno que aparecen después de una tormenta tienen vida?

English: They sure have a lot of energy… I don’t think that’s the same thing though.þ
Korean: 확실히 에너지가 넘치네요... 그래도 똑같은 건 아닌 것 같아요.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Sin duda tienen mucha energía… pero no creo que sea lo mismo.

English: Why not? You don’t think the wind is alive?þ
Korean: 왜 안 돼? 바람이 살아있다고 생각하지 않나요?þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): ¿Por qué no? ¿No crees que el viento tenga vida?

English: Nah… not in the way Kidnas are.þ
So why do they speak so loudly?þ
Korean: 그러면 그들은 왜 그렇게 큰 소리로 말하는 걸까요?þ

English: I guess that’s just the way they roll.þ
Korean: 나는 그것이 그들이 굴러가는 방식이라고 생각합니다.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Supongo que es su forma de ser.

English: No! The Thunder Eggs! What makes them shine so bright? Why do they call out to us?þ
Korean: 아니요! 천둥 알! 무엇이 그들을 그렇게 밝게 빛나게 하는 걸까요? 왜 우리를 부르나요?þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): ¡No, los huevos de trueno! ¿Por qué brillan tanto? ¿Por qué nos llaman?

English: Listen, mate, I like you, I really do, but no flashing rock is speaking to me, I’ll tell you that for free.þ
Korean: 들어보세요, 친구, 난 당신을 좋아해요, 정말로요. 하지만 반짝이는 바위는 나에게 말을 걸지 않습니다. 그 점은 무료로 말씀드리겠습니다.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Escucha, compa, me agradas, de verdad, pero ninguna piedra brillante me habla, ese dato es gratis.

English: Well. Obviously not to you… but they speak all the same.þ
Korean: 잘. 분명히 당신에게는 그렇지 않습니다… 하지만 그들은 모두 똑같이 말합니다.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Bien. Es obvio que a ti no… pero a mí me hablan siempre.

English: It’s pretty strange that we make clothes out of Pleep fur, y’know?þ
Korean: Pleep 모피로 옷을 만든다는 게 참 이상해요.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Es muy extraño que hagamos ropa de piel de ornitorrinco, ¿sabes?

English: I mean, if it’s good enough for them, it’s gotta be good enough for us, right?þ
Korean: 내 말은, 그것이 그들에게 충분하다면 우리에게도 충분할 것이라는 뜻이죠, 그렇죠?þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Digo, si a ellos les sirve, a nosotros también, ¿verdad?

English: Maybe… but if I made a shirt out of your hair, you’d be a bit freaked out.þ
Korean: 어쩌면... 하지만 내가 당신의 머리카락으로 셔츠를 만든다면 당신은 약간 겁을 먹을 것입니다.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Puede ser… pero si hiciera una camiseta con tu cabello, te aterraría un poco.

English: I dunno actually. I guess I’ve never seen it done.þ
Korean: 사실은 모르겠어요. 해본 적이 없는 것 같아요.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): No lo sé, la verdad. Supongo que nunca lo he visto.

English: Hmmm…þ
Does the music at the shop help you work?þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): ¿La música de la tienda te ayuda a trabajar?

English: For the last time, there isn’t any music!þ
…I wonder why you don’t hear it?þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): … Me pregunto por qué no la oyes.

English: You really shouldn’t come in if you’re not buying anything.þ
Korean: 아무것도 사지 않는다면 정말 들어오지 마세요.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): La verdad, no deberías venir si no vas a comprar nada.

English: I just really like that jam, y’know?þ
Korean: 나 그 잼 정말 좋아하는데, 알지?þ

English: …fine.þ
Anyone ever tell you you’re a square?þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): ¿Ya te habían dicho que eres una persona anticuada?

English: I can’t say that they have, no.þ
Korean: 나는 그들이 그렇다고 말할 수 없습니다.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): No creo que lo hayan hecho, no.

English: Well. I just did. Don’t worry, we all are, when you get down to it.þ
Korean: 잘. 방금 했어요. 걱정하지 마십시오. 문제가 발생하면 우리 모두가 그렇습니다.þ

English: Down to what?þ
Anywhere! It’s squares all the way down! Don’t believe me? Start digging.þ
Korean: 어딘가에! 아래는 모두 정사각형이에요! 나를 믿지 못합니까? 발굴을 시작하세요.þ

English: It’s so strange seeing you outside the shop.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Es tan extraño verte fuera de la tienda.

English: It feels strange, too.þ
It’s just… you get used to seeing somebody in a particular place, yknow?þ
Korean: 그건 단지… 특정 장소에서 누군가를 보는 데 익숙해졌을 뿐이죠. 알죠?þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Es que… te acostumbras a ver a alguien en un lugar determinado, ¿sabes?

English: Yeah, I guess that makes sense. þ
Korean: 네, 그게 말이 되는 것 같아요. þ

English: I don’t think I speak to you in your shop.þ
Korean: 내 생각엔 내가 당신 가게에서 당신과 이야기를 나누지 않을 것 같아요.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): No creo que hable contigo en tu tienda.

English: Nah. You don’t buy anything either. Usually you just stand there staring away my customers.þ
Korean: 아니. 당신도 아무것도 사지 않습니다. 보통 당신은 거기 서서 내 고객을 쳐다보곤 합니다.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Nah. Y tampoco compras nada. Por lo general te quedas ahí mirando a los clientes.

English: That’s weird, my shop’s always full of life. Maybe it’s you, y’know?þ
Korean: 이상하네요. 제 가게는 늘 활기가 넘칩니다. 어쩌면 당신일지도 모르죠?þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Qué extraño, mi tienda está siempre llena de vida. Quizás seas tú.

English: What did love feel like?þ
I don't think I can answer that.þ
Korean: 나는 그것에 대답할 수 없을 것 같다.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): No creo que pueda responder eso.

English: I just… how did you know, y’know?þ
Well. She told me. Straight up.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Pues me lo dijo. Sin vueltas.

English: That doesn’t sound romantic at all.þ
Nah, but, listen. When she told me, I knew, too.þ
Korean: 아니, 하지만 들어보세요. 그녀가 나에게 말했을 때 나도 알았다.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Nah, pero escucha, cuando me lo dijo, yo ya lo sabía.

English: How do you stay focused for so long?þ
Korean: 어떻게 그렇게 오랫동안 집중할 수 있나요?þ

English: Dunno. Don’t really think about it.þ
Korean: 몰라. 그것에 대해 정말로 생각하지 마십시오.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): No sé. La verdad no pienso en eso.

English: Oh. Wow. I get it.þ
What’s that?þ
You just kinda, focus by not focusing?þ
Korean: 넌 그냥 초점을 맞추지 않고 집중하는 거야?þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Te concentras sin concentrarte en ello.

English: Sure, whatever you reckon.þ
You close your eyes to see!þ
Do you believe in reincarnation?þ
Is that some kinda fancy flower?þ
I guess sort of… it’s kinda… seasonal, y’know?þ
Korean: 제 생각엔... 그건 좀... 계절적인 것 같아요. 알죠?þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Creo que… de cierta forma… es estacional.

English: I love flowers, me. þ
Oh really? Since when?þ
Hmm. I guess a while back now.þ
Korean: 흠. 지금은 얼마 전인 것 같아요.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Mmm. Supongo que desde hace rato.

English: I think maybe you do.þ
Where did you get that clock of yours?þ
It was so long ago, I really can’t recall.þ
Korean: 너무 오래 전 일이라 기억이 잘 나지 않습니다.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Fue hace tanto, la verdad es que no recuerdo.

English: It has such a loud voice, y’know?þ
It should too, the <Dinks> I spent on it!þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Pues debería, con los <Dinks> que gasté en él

English: You remember the price but not where you got it?þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): ¿Recuerdas el precio pero no dónde lo compraste?

English: I never forget a bill, my dear.
You have a very powerful aura.þ
Korean: 당신은 매우 강력한 아우라를 가지고 있습니다.þ

English: What is that supposed to mean?þ
It’s all… thunderbolts… and solitude.þ
How’s that work?þ
I’m not sure. It’s like… the loneliest storm on the darkest night.þ
Korean: 잘 모르겠습니다. 그것은 마치… 가장 어두운 밤의 가장 외로운 폭풍과 같습니다.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): No lo sé. Es como… la tormenta más solitaria en la noche más oscura.

English: Hmph.þ
Yeah, that’s what I’m talking about! I dig it, y’know?þ
Korean: 응, 그게 바로 내가 말하는 거야! 내가 파는거야, 알지?þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): ¡Sí, a eso me refiero! Me gusta, ¿sabes?

English: You really suit a moustache.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Te queda muy bien el bigote.

English: Thanking you. Dignified, yes?þ
Does that mean “Rah rah rah! Grrrrrr!”? Because, yes. All the way yes.þ
Korean: “라라라!”라는 뜻인가요? 그르르르르!”? 왜냐하면 그렇습니다. 어쨌든 그렇습니다.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): ¿Eso significa "¡Ra, ra, ra! ¡Grrrrrr!"? Porque sí, toda la vida, sí.

English: No!þ
Awwww. That’s a shame, y’know?þ
I’ve been really getting into crystals latelyþ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Últimamente me gustan mucho los cristales.

English: What do they do?þ
It really depends on the type, y’know?þ
Oh?þ
Yeah, some are great for healing, others, the opposite.þ
Korean: 예, 일부는 치유에 좋고 다른 일부는 그 반대입니다.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Sí, algunos sirven para curar, otros, al contrario.

English: What?þ
Oh, nothing. So yeah, the healing ones are great!þ
Korean: 아, 아무것도 아니야. 그래, 치유하는 사람들은 훌륭해!þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Ah, nada. Sí, ¡los que curan son geniales!

English: I guess they just kinda follow their parents?þ
Korean: 그 사람들은 그냥 부모님을 따르는 것 같아요?þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Supongo que solo siguen a sus padres.

English: That sounds sad…þ
No way! They’re all like, “I’mma be better, and bigger! Watch me soar!”þ
Korean: 안 돼요! 그들은 모두 “나는 더 나아지고 더 커질 거야! 내가 솟아오르는 것을 지켜보세요!”þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): ¡Claro que no! Es como si dijeran: "Seré mejor y más grande! ¡Mira cómo crezco!".

English: Then the plant Dad is all “Settle petal.” and  “No, sun!”þ
Korean: 그러면 식물아빠는 모두 '정착꽃잎'이 됩니다. 그리고 "안돼, 태양!"þ

English: Maybe, but then the kid plant is like, I worked harder! I’m the best! Give me a raise!þ
Korean: 어쩌면, 하지만 꼬마 식물은 마치 '내가 더 열심히 일했어요! 내가 최고야! 인상을 줘!þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Quizás, pero luego la planta hijo dice:

English: Does he get it? Does kid plant get the raise?þ
Korean: 그는 그것을 이해합니까? 꼬마 식물이 인상을 받나요?þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): ¿Lo consigue? ¿Le dan el aumento a la planta hijo?

English: Of course! Little guy earned it!þ
Okay. You’ve convinced me. I’m back on Team Plant.þ
Korean: 좋아요. 당신은 나를 설득했습니다. 저는 팀플랜트로 돌아왔습니다.þ

English: Right?!þ
I think those bags of seeds must get pretty wildþ
Korean: 내 생각엔 저 씨앗 봉지가 꽤 거칠어질 것 같아þ

English: Wait, what?þ
Well…they’re young, they’ve got their whole life ahead of them, y’know?þ
Korean: 글쎄요...그들은 어리고 앞으로 남은 인생이 너무 많아요. 알죠?þ

English: Yeah, like, I guess?þ
I bet as soon as you go to sleep… BOOM! Party time!þ
You do some crazy things with hair, y’know?þ
Korean: 당신은 머리카락으로 이상한 짓을 하는군요, 아시죠?þ

English: Thanks!þ
Yeah, you just get in there and bzzzzzzz!þ
I guess I do!þ
Yeah! You go wild! Caution to the wind!
Yeah!þþþ
Bush Devil may care! It doesn’t matter!þ
Korean: 부시 악마는 걱정할 수도 있습니다! 그것은 중요하지 않습니다!þ

English: What?þ
Let’s gooooo!þ
Alright!
I feel like I’ve met you before?þ
When was that?þ
Maybe it hasn’t happened yet?þ
No, it definitely has.þ
How can you be sure though?þ
We’re talking right now!þ
Yeah… but how can you be sure though?þ
Korean: 응… 하지만 어떻게 확신할 수 있나요?þ

English: Ummm… I guess… I’m not anymore?þ
Korean: 음... 아무래도... 난 이제 아닌 것 같은데?þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Emmm… Supongo que… ya no lo estoy.

English: It’ll be nice to meet you!þ
Thanks… um you too?þ
Oh! That’s what it is!þ
What’s that?þ
No! Well, yeah! But, they also just roll right on by. They just keep right on rolling.þ
Korean: 아니요! 글쎄요! 그러나 그들은 또한 바로 옆으로 굴러갑니다. 그들은 계속해서 굴러갑니다.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): ¡No! Digo, sí. Pero también se hacen una bolita y siguen con su vida.

English: I keep on rolling?þ
I know who you remind me of nowþ
Korean: 지금 당신이 누구를 생각나게 하는지 알아요þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Ya sé a quién me recuerdas.

English: Oh, who?þ
A big spiky Kidna.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Un quidna enorme y con espinas.

English: I’m not spiky at all! Wait, why did you say big?!þ
Korean: 나는 전혀 뾰족하지 않습니다! 잠깐, 왜 큰 소리를 했어?!þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): ¡No tengo espinas! Oye, ¿por qué has dicho "enorme"?

English: No, you’re focusing on the wrong part. Kidnas seem kinda shy, y’know?þ
Korean: 아니요, 잘못된 부분에 초점을 맞추고 있습니다. 키드들이 좀 부끄러워하는 것 같죠?þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): No, eso no es lo importante. Los quidnas son algo tímidos, ¿sabes?

English: Yeah, um, I guessþ
But then when things really get tough, y’know what they do?þ
Korean: 하지만 상황이 정말 어려워지면 어떻게 하는지 아시나요?þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Pero cuando las cosas se complican, ¿sabes qué hacen?

English: Um. Spike things?þ
You should stay open later,y’know?þ
We’ve all gotta sleep sometime, darl.þ
Korean: 우리 모두 언젠가는 자야 해, 자기.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Alguna vez hay que dormir, bonita.

English: Boooooo! þ
Yeah, you should definitely sleep more.þ
Boooooo!þ
Nap time for you, I reckon.
Korean: 내 생각엔 당신이 낮잠을 잘 시간인 것 같아요.
Spanish (Latin Americas): Creo que es hora de tu siesta.

English: You ever want to just scrunch all your papers up?þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): ¿A veces no te dan ganas de estrujar tus papeles?

English: What? No!þ
Just tear them to shreds and wing it?þ
That sounds like madness! You’ve gone mad!þ
C’mon Teddy! Live a little!
I’m quite alright, thank you.þ
You ever wonder if we’re in a museum, too?þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): ¿Alguna vez has pensado que estamos en un museo?

English: There’s no way! For one thing, where’s the glass?þ
Korean: 방법이 없습니다! 우선, 유리는 어디에 있나요?þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): ¡Claro que no! En primer lugar, ¿y los cristales?

English: You’re behind glass already! You’re a spectacle!þ
Korean: 당신은 이미 유리 뒤에 있습니다! 당신은 광경입니다!þ

English: I’m bespectacled.þ
Yeah, that’s what I’m saying. There’s probably another Teddy out there right now, collecting all of us!þ
Korean: 응, 그게 내가 말하는 거야. 지금 당장 우리 모두를 모으는 또 다른 테디가 있을 거예요!þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Sí, es lo que digo. Probablemente haya otro Teddy por allí que nos esté coleccionando.

English: Oh! I hope so! I’d love to be a collectable. Mint condition, of course.þ
Korean: 오! 그러기를 바랍니다! 나는 수집품이 되고 싶다. 물론 상태는 최상입니다.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): ¡Ah, ojalá! Me encantaría ser coleccionable. En perfecto estado, claro.

English: What do you think you’ll do when you finish your research paper?þ
Korean: 연구 논문을 마치면 무엇을 할 것 같나요?þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): ¿Qué piensas hacer cuando termines tu trabajo de investigación?

English: Probably I’ll write another one.þ
Korean: 아마 또 다른 글을 쓸 것 같아요.þ

English: Hey, I’m sorry, but I lost that camera I borrowed from you.þ
Korean: 저기, 미안한데 너한테 빌린 카메라를 잃어버렸어.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Oye, lo siento, pero perdí la cámara que te pedí prestada.

English: I don’t um, think I loaned you a camera.þ
Korean: 아니, 음, 내가 당신에게 카메라를 빌려준 것 같아요.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Este… creo que no te presté ninguna cámara.

English: No, I borrowed one though. I lost it.þ
Korean: 아니, 그래도 하나 빌렸어. 나는 그것을 잃었다.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): No, pero te la pedí prestada. La perdí.

English: Oh.þ
Ahhh!
OH NO!
Struth!
HELP!
RUN AWAY!
Predator!
Lovely day, isn’t it?þ
Sure is!þ
Feel the serenity.þ
<IslandName> is too nice.þ
Sure is.þ
I’ll tell you what, I’m having a nice day.þ
Korean: 뭐랄까, 난 좋은 하루를 보내고 있어.þ
Spanish (Latin Americas): Te diré algo, estoy teniendo un gran día.

English: That’s great to hear.þ
I'll tell you what, it's a bloody beauty of a morning.
Korean: 내가 말해줄게, 그것은 아침의 지독한 아름다움이다.

English: I guess you are right...
Morning! þ
Good morning.þ
Hope you have a good one.þ
Breath in that morning air.þ
Alright.þ
I’ll tell you what, it’s not dry is it?þ
Sure isn’t!þ
Sometimes I feel old.þ
Sometimes?þ
I’ll tell you what, it’s really lovely chatting with you.þ
Korean: 내가 말해줄게, 너랑 얘기하는 건 정말 좋은 일이야.þ

English: Likewise!þ
So this power can allow you to see the future?þ
Korean: 그렇다면 이 힘으로 미래를 볼 수 있다는 겁니까?þ

English: Sometimes.þ
And how can I access this power?þ
Korean: 그리고 이 힘에 어떻게 접근할 수 있나요?þ

English: You need to feel it, y’know?þ
Hmmm. Kinetic energy of some sort..þ
No. Not at all!þ
What do you mean my coat is drab?þ
You should come and see me.
I am seeing you now and my coat is just as functional as ever.þ
Korean: 지금 뵙고 있는데 제 코트는 예전처럼 기능적이에요.þ

English: I could make you a nicer coat!þ
Korean: 더 멋진 코트를 만들어줄 수 있어요!þ

English: No thank you. This one is adequate.þ
I have an idea for a motorised machine for sewing.
Korean: 나에게 전동 재봉틀에 대한 아이디어가 있어요.

English: Oh wow!
It will pull in a lot of power though.
Oh, but I don’t want it to mess with my chakras.
Korean: 아, 하지만 내 차크라가 엉망이 되는 건 원하지 않아요.

English: I see.
Have you performed any experiments on your creatures?þ
Korean: 당신의 생물에 대한 실험을 수행한 적이 있습니까?þ

English: Um… no? What?þ
You could make them stronger, faster, better!þ
Korean: 당신은 그들을 더 강하고, 더 빠르고, 더 좋게 만들 수 있습니다!þ

English: I think they’re fine just the way they are, thanks.þ
Korean: 내 생각에는 그 사람들이 있는 그대로 괜찮은 것 같아요. 고마워요.þ

English: But with the right upgradesþ...
I heard you, I’m just not interested, mate.þ
Korean: 들었어, 난 그냥 관심이 없어, 친구.þ

English: Think of the possibilities!þ
Just leave nature alone, yeah?þ
Does the smell not bother you?þ
A little, but you’re not that bad, mate!þ
Korean: 조금, 하지만 그렇게 나쁘지는 않잖아, 친구!þ

English: I am speaking of your creatures.þ
Korean: 나는 당신의 피조물에 대해 말하고 있습니다.þ

English: Oh, maybe. Some of them have really sensitive noses!þ
Korean: 아, 어쩌면. 그들 중 일부는 정말 민감한 코를 가지고 있습니다!þ

English: Things are really taking off, eh?þ
Korean: 정말 일이 잘 풀리고 있어요, 그렇죠?þ

English: Yeah mate, a few more customers since I opened up shop.þ
Korean: 응, 가게를 연 이후로 손님이 몇 ​​명 더 늘었어.þ

English: Oh, so business is good?þ
Korean: 아, 그럼 사업은 잘 되는 거야?þ

English: Well, the thing is, there’s a bit more competition too.
Korean: 글쎄요, 문제는 경쟁도 조금 더 있다는 것입니다.

English: Are you interested in stocking some of my inventions?
Korean: 내 발명품 중 일부를 구입하는 데 관심이 있습니까?

English: That sounds great!
But I need to run my shop!þ
Then this business proposal is now moot.
Korean: 그렇다면 이 사업 제안은 이제 논란의 여지가 있습니다.

English: Well, I have to send a lot back home…þ
I suppose someone back in South City is doing research for you?þ
Korean: South City에 있는 누군가가 당신을 위해 연구를 하고 있는 것 같은데요?þ

English: You could say that…þ
Then I hope you share what you have learnt soon.þ
Korean: 그렇다면 곧 여러분이 배운 내용을 공유하길 바랍니다.þ

English: If all your Dinks could buy infinite knowledge, would you part with them?þ
Korean: 여러분의 모든 Dink가 무한한 지식을 구입할 수 있다면 그들과 헤어지시겠습니까?þ

English: Hmph. Certainly not.þ
But you would know everything.þ
Korean: 하지만 당신은 모든 것을 알고 있을 것입니다.þ

English: If I need something done, I would simply pay someone.þ
Korean: 뭔가 해야 할 일이 있으면 누군가에게 돈을 지불하면 됩니다.þ

English: <IslandName> is amazing for research.þ
I wouldn’t call a place crawling with critters amazing.þ
Korean: 나는 동물들이 기어 다니는 곳을 훌륭하다고 부르지 않을 것입니다.þ

English: But you can play with the very laws of nature here!þ
Korean: 하지만 여기서는 바로 자연의 법칙을 가지고 놀 수 있습니다!þ

English: If there were any laws I would have started suing long ago.
Korean: 만약 법이 있었다면 오래 전부터 고소를 시작했을 겁니다.

English: I am developing a machine that can turn tin into gold
Korean: 주석을 금으로 바꾸는 기계를 개발 중이에요

English: If you need someone to fund your research, talk to me.
Korean: 연구 자금을 지원해 줄 사람이 필요하면 나에게 말하세요.

English: Now that you mention it, I do require a large sum of <Dinks>.
Large sum? Count me out.
How would I do that?þ
Perhaps you could splice the seeds?þ
I could never do that!þ
I do not understand…þ
It would hurt the seeds!þ
I require your assistance.þ
Sure!
Please stop bothering me when I am trying to work.þ
Korean: 제가 일하려고 할 때 저를 괴롭히지 마세요.þ

English: I thought I was helping…þ
You were not.þ
What is your favourite plant?þ
Like, it’s hard to pick one type…þ
Type? I want to see the specific plant.þ
I, like, love them all equally.þ
Impossible.þ
Have you ever considered a different field?þ
Korean: 다른 분야를 생각해 본 적 있나요?þ

English: Further north, you mean?þ
I mean some other occupation.þ
Oh. All the time! But what about my customers?þ
Korean: 오. 항상! 하지만 내 고객은 어떻습니까?þ

English: I believe they would survive.þ
I spent yesterday arranging my instruments.þ
Is that why you cancelled your appointment?þ
I did not make an appointment.þ
I’m free tomorrow, my client list is pretty shortþ.
Korean: 내일 한가해요. 제 고객 목록이 꽤 짧거든요þ.

English: Of that, I am certain.þ
Have you considered adding restraints to your chair?þ
Korean: 의자에 고정 장치를 추가하는 것을 고려해 보셨나요?þ

English: I don’t think it’s going to go anywhereþ.
I was thinking of your customersþ.
Oh, might be an idea, then. Safety first!þ
Korean: 아, 그렇다면 좋은 생각이겠네요. 안전 제일!þ

English: How do you sterilise your equipment?þ
Sterra what?þ
I mean, how do you clean everything?þ
Korean: 내 말은, 모든 것을 어떻게 청소합니까?þ

English: Just good old fashioned elbow grease, darlþ
Korean: 그냥 좋은 구식 팔꿈치 그리스야, 달링þ

English: …I feel ill.þ
They are necessary for my work.þ
I just never see you wear them.þ
Korean: 나는 당신이 그것을 입는 것을 본 적이 없습니다.þ

English: You never see me at work.þ
Korean: 당신은 직장에서 나를 본 적이 없습니다.þ

English: You sure they’re just not for show?þ
Korean: 그냥 보여주기 위한 게 아닌 게 확실해요?þ

English: Do you know why the food has these effects?
Korean: 음식이 왜 이런 영향을 미치는지 아시나요?

English: What difference does that make?
To achieve a deeper understanding!
Would that make it taste better?
What will you do when your collection is complete?þ
Categorization and filing!þ
Of course, but what then?þ
Re-categorization and re-filing!þ
Do you dissect your specimens?þ
Oh, no! I could never do that!þ
Korean: 안 돼! 난 절대 그럴 수 없어!þ

English: Then you are missing out on so much knowledge!þ
Korean: 그렇다면 당신은 너무 많은 지식을 놓치고 있는 것입니다!þ

English: I think um, maybe that’s okay?þ
Korean: 내 생각엔 음, 어쩌면 괜찮은 것 같아?þ

English: How did you collect all of your specimens?þ
Oh! <PlayerName> has been helping.þ
What a remarkable coincidence.þ
Yeah, they’ve been really helpful!þ
I do not wish to speak to you.
Oh… okay?
I will try that some time.
It’s called “being polite”
There is still daylight left.þ
Oh?þ
The sun helps me think.þ
Korean: 태양은 내가 생각하는 데 도움이 됩니다.þ

English: I can not talk for long.þ
Busy today?þ
No, I just do not want to.þ
Korean: 아니요, 그냥 그러고 싶지 않을 뿐입니다.þ

English: I was up all night.
You should take a break.
Good morning.þMorning!þ
Morning!þ
I just had an idea!
This early?þ
Precipitation is a curious phenomenon.
Precipy what now?
I did not learn anything.þ
I do not work well when I am wet.
What does that even mean?
I know for a fact this rain will not stop today.
Korean: 나는 이 비가 오늘 멈추지 않을 것이라는 사실을 알고 있습니다.

English: You’re always so sure of yourself.
So this power can allow you to see the future?þ
Korean: 그렇다면 이 힘으로 미래를 볼 수 있다는 겁니까?þ

English: Sometimes.þ
And how can I access this power?þ
Korean: 그리고 이 힘에 어떻게 접근할 수 있나요?þ

English: You need to feel it, y’know?þ
Hmmm. Kinetic energy of some sort..þ
No. Not at all!þ
What do you mean my coat is drab?þ
You should come and see me.
I am seeing you now and my coat is just as functional as ever.þ
Korean: 지금 뵙고 있는데 제 코트는 예전처럼 기능적이에요.þ

English: I could make you a nicer coat!þ
Korean: 더 멋진 코트를 만들어줄 수 있어요!þ

English: No thank you. This one is adequate.þ
I have an idea for a motorised machine for sewing.
Korean: 나에게 전동 재봉틀에 대한 아이디어가 있어요.

English: Oh wow!
It will pull in a lot of power though.
Oh, but I don’t want it to mess with my chakras.
Korean: 아, 하지만 내 차크라가 엉망이 되는 건 원하지 않아요.

English: I see.
No such license exists.
Well it flamin’ should!þ
That is not for me to decide.þ
Just… be careful, will you?þ
Fine. I will sell only four at a time.þ
Do you remember much about the Shiny Discs?
How old do you think I am?!þ
Honestly, I could not begin to estimate.þ
Korean: 솔직히 나는 추정을 시작할 수 없었습니다.þ

English: Well it was before my time, I’ll tell you what!þ
Korean: 글쎄요, 제 때가 오기 전이었는데, 그걸 말씀드릴게요!þ

English: Did your father ever venture into the deep mines?þ
Korean: 당신의 아버지는 깊은 광산에 들어가 본 적이 있나요?þ

English: Oh, my father went everywhere, I’ll tell you what!þ
Korean: 아, 아버지는 어디든 가셨는데 그게 뭔지 말씀 드리겠습니다!þ

English: Then perhaps you would answer a few questions?þ
Korean: 그렇다면 몇 가지 질문에 답해 주시겠습니까?þ

English: Sure, how long you got?þ
This island must have been remarkable in its heyday.þ
Korean: 이 섬은 전성기에 주목할만한 곳이었을 것입니다.þ

English: What do you mean?þ
All of these artifacts show a fantastic level of technology.
Korean: 이 유물들은 모두 환상적인 수준의 기술을 보여줍니다.

English: That would’ve been long before my father’s time, I’ll tell you what!
Korean: 그건 우리 아버지 시대보다 오래 전의 일이겠죠. 제가 말씀드리겠습니다!

English: Oh...
He always used to come home with strange items like thatþ...
Korean: 그 사람은 항상 그런 이상한 물건을 가지고 집에 오곤 했어요þ...

English: Have you performed any experiments on your creatures?þ
Korean: 당신의 생물에 대한 실험을 수행한 적이 있습니까?þ

English: Um… no? What?þ
You could make them stronger, faster, better!þ
Korean: 당신은 그들을 더 강하고, 더 빠르고, 더 좋게 만들 수 있습니다!þ

English: I think they’re fine just the way they are, thanks.þ
Korean: 내 생각에는 그 사람들이 있는 그대로 괜찮은 것 같아요. 고마워요.þ

English: But with the right upgradesþ...
I heard you, I’m just not interested, mate.þ
Korean: 들었어, 난 그냥 관심이 없어, 친구.þ

English: Think of the possibilities!þ
Just leave nature alone, yeah?þ
Does the smell not bother you?þ
A little, but you’re not that bad, mate!þ
Korean: 조금, 하지만 그렇게 나쁘지는 않잖아, 친구!þ

English: I am speaking of your creatures.þ
Korean: 나는 당신의 피조물에 대해 말하고 있습니다.þ

English: Oh, maybe. Some of them have really sensitive noses!þ
Korean: 아, 어쩌면. 그들 중 일부는 정말 민감한 코를 가지고 있습니다!þ

English: Your tools are inferior to anything I can craft.þ
Korean: 당신의 도구는 내가 만들 수 있는 어떤 도구보다 열등합니다.þ

English: My tools are much cheaper though.þ
Yes they are.þ
But, they get the job done!þ
Yes they do. Slowly.þ
Why do I talk to you…þ
Korean: 내가 왜 너한테 말을 하는 거지...þ

English: Are you interested in stocking some of my inventions?
Korean: 내 발명품 중 일부를 구입하는 데 관심이 있습니까?

English: That sounds great!
But I need to run my shop!þ
Then this business proposal is now moot.
Korean: 그렇다면 이 사업 제안은 이제 논란의 여지가 있습니다.

English: Well, I have to send a lot back home…þ
I suppose someone back in South City is doing research for you?þ
Korean: South City에 있는 누군가가 당신을 위해 연구를 하고 있는 것 같은데요?þ

English: You could say that…þ
Then I hope you share what you have learnt soon.þ
Korean: 그렇다면 곧 여러분이 배운 내용을 공유하길 바랍니다.þ

English: If all your Dinks could buy infinite knowledge, would you part with them?þ
Korean: 여러분의 모든 Dink가 무한한 지식을 구입할 수 있다면 그들과 헤어지시겠습니까?þ

English: Hmph. Certainly not.þ
But you would know everything.þ
Korean: 하지만 당신은 모든 것을 알고 있을 것입니다.þ

English: If I need something done, I would simply pay someone.þ
Korean: 뭔가 해야 할 일이 있으면 누군가에게 돈을 지불하면 됩니다.þ

English: <IslandName> is amazing for research.þ
I wouldn’t call a place crawling with critters amazing.þ
Korean: 나는 동물들이 기어 다니는 곳을 훌륭하다고 부르지 않을 것입니다.þ

English: But you can play with the very laws of nature here!þ
Korean: 하지만 여기서는 바로 자연의 법칙을 가지고 놀 수 있습니다!þ

English: If there were any laws I would have started suing long ago.
Korean: 만약 법이 있었다면 오래 전부터 고소를 시작했을 겁니다.

English: I am developing a machine that can turn tin into gold
Korean: 주석을 금으로 바꾸는 기계를 개발 중이에요

English: If you need someone to fund your research, talk to me.
Korean: 연구 자금을 지원해 줄 사람이 필요하면 나에게 말하세요.

English: Now that you mention it, I do require a large sum of <Dinks>.
Large sum? Count me out.
How would I do that?þ
Perhaps you could splice the seeds?þ
I could never do that!þ
I do not understand…þ
It would hurt the seeds!þ
I require your assistance.þ
Sure!
Please stop bothering me when I am trying to work.þ
Korean: 제가 일하려고 할 때 저를 괴롭히지 마세요.þ

English: I thought I was helping…þ
You were not.þ
What is your favourite plant?þ
Like, it’s hard to pick one type…þ
Type? I want to see the specific plant.þ
I, like, love them all equally.þ
Impossible.þ
Have you ever considered a different field?þ
Korean: 다른 분야를 생각해 본 적 있나요?þ

English: Further north, you mean?þ
I mean some other occupation.þ
Oh. All the time! But what about my customers?þ
Korean: 오. 항상! 하지만 내 고객은 어떻습니까?þ

English: I believe they would survive.þ
I spent yesterday arranging my instruments.þ
Is that why you cancelled your appointment?þ
I did not make an appointment.þ
I’m free tomorrow, my client list is pretty shortþ.
Korean: 내일 한가해요. 제 고객 목록이 꽤 짧거든요þ.

English: Of that, I am certain.þ
Have you considered adding restraints to your chair?þ
Korean: 의자에 고정 장치를 추가하는 것을 고려해 보셨나요?þ

English: I don’t think it’s going to go anywhereþ.
I was thinking of your customersþ.
Oh, might be an idea, then. Safety first!þ
Korean: 아, 그렇다면 좋은 생각이겠네요. 안전 제일!þ

English: How do you sterilise your equipment?þ
Sterra what?þ
I mean, how do you clean everything?þ
Korean: 내 말은, 모든 것을 어떻게 청소합니까?þ

English: Just good old fashioned elbow grease, darlþ
Korean: 그냥 좋은 구식 팔꿈치 그리스야, 달링þ

English: …I feel ill.þ
They are necessary for my work.þ
I just never see you wear them.þ
Korean: 나는 당신이 그것을 입는 것을 본 적이 없습니다.þ

English: You never see me at work.þ
Korean: 당신은 직장에서 나를 본 적이 없습니다.þ

English: You sure they’re just not for show?þ
Korean: 그냥 보여주기 위한 게 아닌 게 확실해요?þ

English: Do you know why the food has these effects?
Korean: 음식이 왜 이런 영향을 미치는지 아시나요?

English: What difference does that make?
To achieve a deeper understanding!
Would that make it taste better?
What will you do when your collection is complete?þ
Categorization and filing!þ
Of course, but what then?þ
Re-categorization and re-filing!þ
Do you dissect your specimens?þ
Oh, no! I could never do that!þ
Korean: 안 돼! 난 절대 그럴 수 없어!þ

English: Then you are missing out on so much knowledge!þ
Korean: 그렇다면 당신은 너무 많은 지식을 놓치고 있는 것입니다!þ

English: I think um, maybe that’s okay?þ
Korean: 내 생각엔 음, 어쩌면 괜찮은 것 같아?þ

English: How did you collect all of your specimens?þ
Oh! <PlayerName> has been helping.þ
What a remarkable coincidence.þ
Yeah, they’ve been really helpful!þ
G'day
Nice to see you, {0}
Hello, {0}
G'day, {0}
But they are so cute!
I wouldn't say that...
Oh, they string alright.
Only if you touch them.
Bloody beauty of a day!
Yeah it is.
Bloody beauty of a morning!
Yeah, I guess.
Good morning, mate!
Morning!
Struth! You see that sunrise?
I wasn't really paying attention...
Pleep would love this weather!
Korean: Pleep은 이 날씨를 좋아할 것 같아요!

English: Sure would!
Good to have a wind down.
I reckon.
What do you mean you won't?
I can't look after a Chook, mate.
What do you reckon is your favourite material to work with?þ
Korean: 작업할 때 가장 좋아하는 재료는 무엇이라고 생각하시나요?þ

English: Dreams… always dreams. Only dreams.þ
That material will last a while, then?þ
Korean: 그럼 그 자료는 꽤 오래 갈 것 같은데요?þ

English: My, yes. The right one will last you a lifetime. The worst ones too.þ
Korean: 내, 그래. 올바른 것은 평생 지속될 것입니다. 최악의 것들도 마찬가지다.þ

English: You got any new designs coming in?þ
Yeah! I’ve been working on a new stealth shirt.þ
Korean: 응! 나는 새로운 스텔스 셔츠를 작업하고 있어요.þ

English: Aw yeah? Solid black then?þ
Not even close. It’s super bright with all kinds of patterns and colours.þ
Korean: 가깝지도 않아요. 다양한 패턴과 색상으로 매우 밝습니다.þ

English: How’s that work? Everybody would be staring at you, yeah?þ
No way! It’s impossible to look at without throwing up.þ
Korean: 안 돼요! 토하지 않고 보는 것은 불가능합니다.þ

English: Oh.. cool? Nearly finished that one then?þ
Korean: 아..멋져? 그럼 그거 거의 다 끝났어?þ

English: I don’t know. I just don’t know.
Hey, you were right about that thing the other day.þ
Korean: 저번에 그 문제에 관해서는 당신 말이 옳았어요.þ

English: I usually am.þ
I just don’t get how you could possibly have known.þ
Korean: 나는 당신이 어떻게 알았을 수 있었는지 모르겠습니다.þ

English: I get hunches sometimes, y’know?þ
Yeah mate… but khaki? What are the odds I would have worn khaki that day?!þ
Korean: 응 친구… 그런데 카키색? 그날 내가 카키색 옷을 입었을 확률은 얼마나 될까요?!þ

English: I swear this Jackaroo was trying to talk to me the other day.þ
Korean: 저 Jackaroo가 저번에 나한테 말을 걸려고 했었다고 맹세해요.þ

English: Talk to you? With it’s voice?þ
I tried, mate, but far out, are they fast!þ
Korean: 시도해 봤는데, 친구, 그런데 너무 빠르네요!þ

English: Yeah! Well, sort of. It was kind of clicking? I understood it though, I think.þ
Korean: 응! 글쎄요. 클릭 정도였나요? 그래도 이해한 것 같아요.þ

English: Wow. What did it say?þ
Something about little Timmy and a well?þ
Who’s Timmy?þ
Not sure. Must be one of his mates or something?þ
Korean: 확실하지 않습니다. 그의 동료 중 한 명이겠죠?þ

English: Makes sense. What happened next?þ
Korean: 말이 되네요. 다음에 무슨 일이 일어났나요?þ

English: Well, it just hopped away!þ
Did you follow it?þ
I can see why you wanted to come back here, this place is unreal!þ
Korean: 왜 여기로 돌아오고 싶어했는지 알겠습니다. 이곳은 비현실적입니다!þ

English: Yeah, there’s something about <IslandName> I just can’t shake, I’ll tell you what!þ
Korean: 네, <IslandName>에는 뭔가가 있어서 도저히 떨칠 수가 없네요. 그 점을 말씀드릴게요!þ

English: It’s like I didn’t know I was alive til I had a Wary Mu bearing down on me. Crikey! The sight of it crashing through that lush beautiful foliage!þ
Korean: Wary Mu가 나를 압박하기 전까지는 내가 살아 있다는 것을 몰랐던 것과 같습니다. 크리키! 그 무성하고 아름다운 나뭇잎 사이로 부서지는 광경!þ

English: It’s their island too, mate.þ
Don’t I know it! I wouldn’t have it any other way.þ
Korean: 나는 그것을 모른다! 다른 방법은 없을 것입니다.þ

English: Your dad sounds like a true blue legend.þ
Korean: 네 아버지는 진짜 푸른 전설 같으시다.þ

English: He sure was, I’ll tell you what!þ
Always doing something, always on the go, breaking new ground.þ
Korean: 항상 무언가를 하고, 이동 중에도 새로운 영역을 개척합니다.þ

English: Yeah. I think that’s why <SouthCity> was so hard on him. All that potential and energy, and nothing to do with it.þ
Korean: 응. 그래서 <사우스시티>가 그토록 힘들었던 것 같아요. 그 모든 잠재력과 에너지, 그리고 그것과는 아무런 관련이 없습니다.þ

English: Such a shame. I reckon he’d be proud of you though, hey.þ
Korean: 정말 부끄러운 일입니다. 내 생각엔 그 사람이 당신을 자랑스러워할 것 같아요.þ

English: So have you done any work on critters before?þ
Korean: 그럼 이전에 동물에 대한 작업을 해본 적이 있나요?þ

English: No, but how hard can it possibly be? We are just simple machines, after all.þ
Korean: 아니, 하지만 얼마나 힘들 수 있을까요? 결국 우리는 단순한 기계일 뿐입니다.þ

English: I think there’s a bit more to it than that, mate.þ
Korean: 내 생각엔 그것보다 더 많은 일이 있을 것 같아, 친구.þ

English: I do not see you wearing a white coat.þ
Korean: 나는 당신이 흰 코트를 입고 있는 것을 보지 못했습니다.þ

English: I’ve been meaning to ask you about that. What’s the go with it?þ
Korean: 나는 그것에 대해 당신에게 물어볼 생각이었습니다. 무슨 일이야?þ

English: It’s nice to see you turning all that trash into something useful.þ
Korean: 그 모든 쓰레기를 유용한 것으로 바꾸는 모습을 보니 반갑습니다.þ

English: It is only trash to the layman. There is a font of knowledge beneath our feet.þ
Korean: 평신도에게는 쓰레기일 뿐입니다. 우리 발 아래에는 지식의 샘이 있습니다.þ

English: The main thing is, you’re helping keep <IslandName> beautiful.þ
Korean: 중요한 것은 여러분이 <IslandName>을 아름답게 유지하는 데 도움을 주고 있다는 것입니다.þ

English: That is not the main thing.þ
In a way, you’re sort of a bin-man extraordinaire!þ
Korean: 어떤 면에서 당신은 일종의 빈맨(bin-man) 비범한 사람입니다!þ

English: Another hard night of work, mate?þ
We shall see what tonight brings, yes.þ
Korean: 우리는 오늘 밤에 무슨 일이 일어날지 지켜볼 것입니다. 그렇습니다.þ

English: I don’t know how you do it. If I don’t get a solid ten hours rest, I’m bushed!þ
Korean: 어떻게 하는지 모르겠어요. 10시간 동안 제대로 쉬지 않으면 난 망할 거예요!þ

English: Ten whole hours of downtime? That sounds incredibly wasteful.þ
Korean: 10시간의 다운타임이 있었나요? 그것은 엄청나게 낭비적인 것 같습니다.þ

English: I’d never call a good night’s sleep a waste!þ
Korean: 나는 숙면을 취하는 것을 결코 낭비라고 부르지 않을 것입니다!þ

English: Hey mate, I’ve been meaning to talk to you about that shovel you sold me.þ
Korean: 안녕 친구, 당신이 나에게 판 삽에 대해 이야기하려고 했어요.þ

English: Don’t you just love it?þ
Not really mate, no, the handle snapped off first time I used it.þ
Korean: 별로 친구가 아닙니다. 아니요. 처음 사용했을 때 손잡이가 부러졌습니다.þ

English: Aw yeah? I reckon I musta sold you a newer model by mistake.þ
Korean: 아 그래요? 내 생각엔 내가 실수로 당신에게 새 모델을 팔았나 봐요.þ

English: What’s the difference?þ
Well, it’s convertible, yeah? Folds away for easy storage.þ
Korean: 음, 컨버터블이군요, 그렇죠? 쉽게 보관할 수 있도록 접습니다.þ

English: Storage? Mate, I’m storing it in my bin.þ
Korean: 저장? 친구, 난 그것을 쓰레기통에 보관하고 있어요.þ

English: How do you know you’re getting good quality Bush Limes in?þ
Korean: 좋은 품질의 부시 라임이 들어가는지 어떻게 알 수 있나요?þ

English: No worries there, I don’t eat my own stock.þ
Korean: 걱정하지 마세요. 저는 제 주식을 먹지 않습니다.þ

English: What? Why not?þ
Why would I eat my profits? Mate, they grow outside for free!þ
Korean: 내가 왜 이익을 먹겠어요? 친구, 그들은 무료로 밖에서 자랍니다!þ

English: I found this huge chunk of amber the other day. A real beauty, it was.þ
Korean: 얼마전에 이 거대한 호박덩어리를 발견했어요. 정말 아름다움이었습니다.þ

English: Bring it round the shop mate, I’ll give you a great price for it.þ
Korean: 상점 친구에게 가져오시면 좋은 가격으로 제공해 드리겠습니다.þ

English: Aw yeah? How much?þ
Depends how much it weighs. Just chuck it on the scales at the shop, and I’ll tell you.þ
Korean: 무게가 얼마나 되는지에 따라 다릅니다. 가게 저울에 올려놓으면 알려드릴게요.þ

English: Can’t I just weigh it myself?þ
Korean: 내가 직접 무게를 측정할 수는 없나요?þ

English: Nah. I got these scales made special. Real special.þ
Korean: 아니. 나는 이 저울을 특별하게 만들었습니다. 진짜 스페셜.þ

English: You musta seen some crazy things in your time.þ
Korean: 당신은 당신의 시간에 미친 것들을 보았을 것입니다.þ

English: Yeah mate.þ
Must have a few stories, yeah?þ
Korean: 몇 가지 이야기가 있을 텐데요, 그렇죠?þ

English: Yeah mate.þ
Nice.
You can tell you put a lot of care into your work.þ
Korean: 작업에 많은 신경을 썼다는 것을 알 수 있습니다.þ

English: No other way to do it.þ
I admire that, I do, mate.þ
What’s that?þ
A bit of care and attention. Professionalism. You’re a bloody legend, mate.þ
Korean: 약간의 관심과 관심. 전문 직업 의식. 당신은 정말 전설적인 존재예요, 친구.þ

English: Nah. Just a fella with a chisel and a bit of free time, is all.þ
Korean: 아니. 단지 끌과 약간의 자유 시간을 가진 친구가 전부입니다.þ

English: You been gettin in those quality winks, old mate?þ
Always do.þ
You beauty.
You been keeping alright, mate?þ
Absolutely. Top of my game.þ
What game’s that, then?þ
The only game in town, my friend, <Dinks>, of course!þ
Korean: 동네의 유일한 게임, 내 친구 <딩크스>는 물론!þ

English: How’s my account tracking along?þ
Terrific. It’s precisely as empty as when you opened it.þ
Korean: 훌륭한. 열었을 때와 마찬가지로 텅 비어 있습니다.þ

English: That’s a shame. No interest then?þ
As I’ve told you before, you’ll need to deposit actual <Dinks> firstþ
Korean: 앞서 말씀드린 대로 실제 <Dinks>를 먼저 입금하셔야 합니다.þ

English: Well, what am I paying you for, then?þ
Korean: 그렇다면 내가 당신에게 무엇을 지불하고 있습니까?þ

English: I can assure you, you’re not.
Korean: 나는 당신에게 확신할 수 있습니다. 당신은 그렇지 않습니다.

English: You ever owned a pet, mate?þ
Me? Don’t be absurd. All that work without any benefit sounds preposterous!þ
Korean: 나? 터무니없는 소리하지 마십시오. 어떤 이익도 없이 작동하는 모든 것이 터무니없는 것처럼 들립니다!þ

English: It’s not work if you love doing it, besides, don’t you wish there was somebody or something that was happy to see you when you got home?þ
Korean: 당신이 그 일을 좋아한다면 그것은 일이 아닙니다. 게다가 당신이 집에 돌아왔을 때 당신을 반가워해줄 누군가나 무언가가 있었으면 하고 바라지 않습니까?þ

English: I’m happy enough, thank you very much, and I could see myself all day!
Korean: 충분히 행복하고, 정말 감사하고, 하루종일 제 모습을 볼 수 있었어요!

English: You seem like you’ve got a really kind heart.þ
That’s so sweet. What makes you say that?þ
Korean: 정말 달콤해요. 왜 그런 말을 하게 됐나요?þ

English: The effort you put into nurturing those plants. It’s unreal!þ
Korean: 그 식물을 키우기 위해 쏟은 ​​노력. 비현실적이에요!þ

English: Everything deserves a chance to like, grow, right?þ
Korean: 모든 것은 좋아하고 성장할 기회를 가질 자격이 있습니다. 그렇죠?þ

English: Spot on, I reckon.þ
You ever thought about getting a pet?þ
Korean: 애완동물을 키울 생각을 해본 적 있나요?þ

English: No way. I mean, like, Pleep are so soft and friendly, but, I get like, really forgetful sometimes?þ
Korean: 안 돼요. 내 말은, Pleep은 너무 부드럽고 친절하지만 가끔은 정말 잊어 버리나요?þ

English: You're worried you wouldn’t be able to take care of one properly?þ
Yeah, exactly!þ
Don’t worry about that, mate, they’re pretty good at reminding you if they’re hungry.þ
Korean: 걱정하지 마세요, 친구. 그들은 배가 고프면 알려주는 데 꽤 능숙합니다.þ

English: Just like people, then!þ
Too right!þ
How’s the soil game, love?þ
It’s been like, off the hook!þ
Korean: 그것은 마치, 마치, 당장에 있었던 것 같았습니다!þ

English: Aw yeah?þ
Yeah. I keep unearthing strange machines and freaky greasy parts.þ
Korean: 응. 나는 이상한 기계와 이상하게 기름진 부품을 계속 발굴합니다.þ

English: People just throwing them away, eh? No respect for nature, I reckon.þ
Korean: 사람들이 그냥 버리는 거죠? 자연을 존중하지 않는 것 같아요.þ

English: Yeah. It’s a little sad, but I kinda love it? It’s like a little adventure every time!þ
Korean: 응. 조금 아쉽긴 하지만 그래도 좀 마음에 드는데? 매번 작은 모험과 같습니다!þ

English: Hey Shazza! Haven’t seen you in ages.þ
Korean: 안녕 샤자! 오랫동안 당신을 보지 못했습니다.þ

English: Yeah, it’s been a while.þ
You still shearing?þ
Until I figure something else out, yeah.þ
Korean: 내가 뭔가 다른 걸 알아내기 전까지는요.þ

English: You do something you love, you never work a day in your life!þ
Korean: 당신은 당신이 좋아하는 일을 하고, 당신의 인생에서 하루도 일하지 않습니다!þ

English: Don’t come near me with those scissors, hey. I’m letting these little fellas grow out.þ
Korean: 그 가위 들고 나한테 다가오지 마, 야. 나는이 작은 친구들이 자라도록 내버려 둘 것입니다.þ

English: I don’t think my scissors would be able to. Your hair’s so thick!þ
Korean: 내 가위로는 그럴 수 없을 것 같아요. 머리카락이 너무 굵어요!þ

English: Thanks! Sunlight and exercise, mate.þ
I better start running on the beach then!þ
Korean: 그럼 해변에서 달리기 시작하는 게 좋을 것 같아요!þ

English: G’day Shazza! Any new goss?þ
You know I can’t breach barber-patron confidentiality!þ
Korean: 나는 이발사 후원자의 기밀을 위반할 수 없다는 것을 알고 있습니다!þ

English: That’s a thing, is it?þ
Well, it is now, since you’ve been blabbing all my juicy stories all over town!þ
Korean: 글쎄요, 당신이 내 흥미진진한 이야기를 온 동네에서 떠들고 있으니까 지금이군요!þ

English: To be fair, they were great stories.þ
I know! I’ve got so many more too!þ
Korean: 알아요! 나에겐 그 외에도 많은 것이 있다!þ

English: How do you sterilise your equipment?þ
Sterra what?þ
I mean, how do you clean everything?þ
Korean: 내 말은, 모든 것을 어떻게 청소합니까?þ

English: Just good old fashioned elbow grease, darlþ
Korean: 그냥 좋은 구식 팔꿈치 그리스야, 달링þ

English: …I feel ill.þ
They are necessary for my work.þ
I just never see you wear them.þ
Korean: 나는 당신이 그것을 입는 것을 본 적이 없습니다.þ

English: You never see me at work.þ
Korean: 당신은 직장에서 나를 본 적이 없습니다.þ

English: You sure they’re just not for show?þ
Korean: 그냥 보여주기 위한 게 아닌 게 확실해요?þ

English: Do you know why the food has these effects?
Korean: 음식이 왜 이런 영향을 미치는지 아시나요?

English: What difference does that make?
To achieve a deeper understanding!
Would that make it taste better?
How’s a fella like you get so adventurous?þþþ
Korean: 너 같은 친구가 어떻게 그렇게 모험을 좋아하는 거지?þþþ

English: Oh. Um. I’m not sure what you mean?þ
Korean: 오. 음. 무슨 뜻인지 잘 모르겠나요?þ

English: Well, packing it all up and moving to <IslandName>. You don’t strike me as the outdoors type.þ
Korean: 자, 모든 것을 정리하고 <IslandName>으로 이동합니다. 당신은 나를 야외 활동 유형으로 생각하지 않습니다.þ

English: Not typically, but there’s so much research to be done here, it’s a fascinating place.
Korean: 일반적이지는 않지만 여기서 수행해야 할 연구가 너무 많아서 매력적인 곳입니다.

English: You’ll have to give me a tour of your place, mate.þ
Korean: 당신이 있는 곳을 나한테 안내해 줘야 할 거예요, 친구.þ

English: That’d be grand! I’d love that. Just wait until you see my collection of paperclips!þ
Korean: 정말 대단할 것 같아요! 나는 그것을 좋아할 것입니다. 내 클립 컬렉션을 볼 때까지 기다리세요!þ

English: I was thinking more about the critters, to be honest.þ
Korean: 솔직히 말해서 나는 동물에 대해 더 많이 생각하고 있었습니다.þ

English: They’ve already seen the paperclips. Oh! Only in their original order though. Maybe I could try reverse alphabetical?þ
Korean: 그들은 이미 클립을 본 적이 있습니다. 오! 하지만 원래 순서대로만 가능합니다. 어쩌면 알파벳 역순으로 시도해 볼 수도 있을까요?þ

English: Yeah… righto mate. Sounds like a hoot.
What kinda line have you been using for the fish you’re keeping?þ
Korean: 당신이 키우고 있는 물고기에 어떤 종류의 낚싯줄을 사용하고 있나요?þ

English: Line?þ
Yeah, what’re you reeling them in with?þ
Korean: 그래, 넌 뭘로 끌어들이고 있는 거야?þ

English: Oh. Um. Mostly Permit Points.þ
Is that successful?þ
Oh yes! You could fill a whole museum if you have enough!þ
Korean: 아 그래요! 충분하다면 박물관 전체를 채울 수도 있습니다!þ

English: Happy {0} Day!
Happy {0} Day, {1}
I’m taking today off.þ
You take days off?þ
How are you going today?
Not bad, mate.
How’s this weather?
At least it’s not raining.
Another day, another <Dink>
You need more time off, mate.
I guess I should get going.
Are you busy today?
I'm always busy.
Morning, mate.
Morning.
Nice weather for Pleep.
Sure is!
Sure is wet today.
Because it’s raining?
I love the rain.
I wish I could say the same today.
Korean: 오늘도 같은 말을 할 수 있었으면 좋겠습니다.

English: Sometimes, you seem a little creepy.þ
Korean: 가끔 당신은 조금 소름 끼치는 것처럼 보입니다.þ

English: Kinda creepy for you to notice, y’know?þ
What?! No it isn’t!þ
Now you’re shouting? Such a creep.þ
Korean: 지금 소리 지르는 거야? 그런 소름 끼치는 소리.þ

English: …sorry.þ
Do you think I could sell some of your clothes in my shop?þ
Korean: 내가 당신 옷을 내 가게에서 팔 수 있을 것 같아요?þ

English: I really don’t think they’d be happy there y’know?þ
Korean: 난 정말 그 사람들이 그곳에서 행복할 거라고 생각하지 않아요. 알죠?þ

English: Nah, I think they’d love it!þ
Korean: 아니, 내 생각엔 그들이 좋아할 것 같아!þ

English: That’s okay. You can think that.
Nah mate, I haven't seen my brother in years.þ
Korean: 아니 친구, 나는 몇 년 동안 내 동생을 보지 못했습니다.þ

English: He's probably closer than you think, y'know?þ
Korean: 그 사람은 아마 당신이 생각하는 것보다 더 가까이 있을 거예요.þ

English: Ease up on the mumbo jumbo a little, yeah? This is family we're talking about.þ
Korean: 멍청한 짓은 좀 진정해, 응? 이것이 우리가 이야기하고 있는 가족입니다.þ

English: I'm just saying, family has a way of finding you, don't you think?þ
Korean: 내 말은, 가족이 당신을 찾을 수 있는 방법이 있다는 거죠, 그렇죠?þ

English: For once I think you're speaking sense. He'll find me alright, when he's short on Dinks
Korean: 일단 나는 당신이 말이 되는 말을 하고 있다고 생각합니다. 그 사람은 Dinks가 부족해도 내가 괜찮다고 생각할 거야

English: Hey, about that licence giving licence…þ
Korean: 아, 그 면허 주는 면허 말인데…þ

English: Yeah, I’m really proud of that one.þ
You got any spares?þ
I really couldn’t give you one.þ
I could really use it though.þ
I don’t have a licence to give the licence giving licence!þ
Korean: 면허를 주는 면허를 줄 면허가 없어요!þ

English: This sure is a beautiful place. Is it like you remembered?þ
Korean: 이곳은 확실히 아름다운 곳이에요. 당신이 기억하는 것과 같나요?þ

English: Mostly, yeah. I forgot how colourful everything was. <SouthCity> was so grey and lifeless.
Korean: 대부분 그렇습니다. 나는 모든 것이 얼마나 다채로운 지 잊어 버렸습니다. <SouthCity>는 너무나 회색빛이었고 생명이 없었습니다.

English: Not for much longer, with the amount of fish and bugs I’ve been selling to them!þ
Korean: 내가 그들에게 팔았던 물고기와 벌레의 양이 너무 많아서 오래 가지 못했습니다!þ

English: Maybe you’re right, but I don’t think it works like that.
Korean: 어쩌면 당신 말이 맞을지도 모르지만, 내 생각엔 그렇게는 안 될 것 같아요.

English: Oh?
That place drains all the colour and life out of you.þ
Korean: 그 곳은 당신에게서 모든 색과 생명을 빼앗아갑니다.þ

English: I’ve been thinking about branching out and selling Cactus Figs, whaddya reckon?þ
Korean: 선인장 무화과(Cactus Figs)를 사업화해서 판매하려고 생각하고 있었는데, 어떻게 생각하시나요?þ

English: I don’t like the sound of that, I’ll tell you what! Those things are terrible for my belly.þ
Korean: 나는 그 소리가 마음에 들지 않습니다. 무엇인지 말씀 드리겠습니다! 그런 것들은 내 배에 끔찍합니다.þ

English: Yeah, I don’t like them either to be honest. But what’s the harm in selling a couple?þ
Korean: 응, 솔직히 말해서 나도 그 사람들을 좋아하지 않아. 그런데 커플을 파는 게 무슨 해가 됩니까?þ

English: Prickles, that’s the harm. Those buggers are ruthless!þ
Korean: 프리클스, 그게 해악이야. 저 놈들은 무자비해요!þ

English: Are you trying to steal my customers, mate?þ
That is not my intention.
Well, they’re all talking about your fancy gizmos and gadgets!þ
Korean: 글쎄, 그들은 모두 당신의 멋진 장치와 장치에 대해 이야기하고 있습니다!þ

English: I suppose some people just have an eye for quality.þ
Korean: 품질에만 눈을 돌리는 사람들이 있는 것 같아요.þ

English: My tools are as quality as they come!þ
Do not worry. I will not stoop to selling fruits and vegetables.
Korean: 걱정하지 마세요. 나는 과일과 채소를 파는 일에 굴하지 않을 것입니다.

English: You charge a heck of a lot for your contraptions.þ
Korean: 당신은 당신의 장치에 대해 엄청난 비용을 청구합니다.þ

English: I charge precisely what they are worth.þ
I don’t suppose you do mates rates?þ
Korean: 당신이 친구 요금을 지불한다고 생각하지 않습니까?þ

English: You can pay me more if you wish, yes.þ
Y’know, I don’t think I’ve ever seen you actually build anything.
Korean: 알다시피, 당신이 실제로 뭔가를 만드는 것을 본 적이 없는 것 같아요.

English: If you like your fancy machines so much, why’d you come here? There’s heaps more of those in <SouthCity>!þ
Korean: 당신의 멋진 기계가 그토록 마음에 든다면 왜 여기에 왔나요? <SouthCity>에는 그런 것들이 더 많아요!þ

English: Indeed there are. Decrepit, noisy, rusty machines in need of enhancement.þ
Korean: 실제로 그렇습니다. 노후하고 시끄럽고 녹슨 기계는 개선이 필요합니다.þ

English: So why aren’t you back there fixing those up?þ
Korean: 그럼 거기로 돌아가서 문제를 해결하지 그래?þ

English: One word. Paperwork.þ
Hah! That’s three words, you gallah!þ
How did you get into the animal business?þ
It’s not really a business, mate.þ
Okay, sure. How did you, though?þ
I’m just love all critters, great and small.
Korean: 나는 크고 작은 모든 동물을 사랑합니다.

English: I sell a fair few bugs myselfþ.
What do people do with them?þ
Y’know, I never asked.þ
Are they safe, and cared for?þ
Well, I put a few airholes in the boxes, yeah.
Korean: 글쎄요, 상자에 공기 구멍 몇 개를 뚫었습니다.

English: You ever seen an alpha Pleep?þ
Crikey! I wish! You’d here them cooing for miles!þþ
Korean: 크리키! 나는 바란다! 당신은 그들이 몇 마일 동안 구구거리고 있을 것입니다!þþ

English: I wouldn’t go anywhere near a giant one. They’d knock you for six.þ
Korean: 나는 거대한 것 근처에도 가지 않을 것입니다. 그들은 당신을 6번 노크할 것입니다.þ

English: A pleep? No way! Even massive, there’s no way they’d have it in them. Real gentle, I reckon. True softies.þ
Korean: 플리프? 안 돼요! 아무리 거대하더라도 그 안에 들어있을 리가 없습니다. 정말 온화하다고 생각합니다. 진정한 부드러움.þ

English: Softies… yeah… come to think of it, you’d get wool enough for the whole island.þ
Korean: Softies... 응... 그러고 보니 섬 전체를 통틀어 쓸 만큼의 양털을 얻을 수 있을 텐데.þ

English: Trust you to be thinking about the profits.þ
Nah, just the wool. You know me mate, I love a good yarn.þ
Korean: 아뇨, 그냥 양털이에요. 저 아시죠? 저는 좋은 털실을 좋아해요.þ

English: You really take your time making stuff.þ
Korean: 당신은 정말 시간을 들여 물건을 만드는군요.þ

English: Cheers. You gotta make ‘em right.þ
I mean, I ordered those shelves…þ
Korean: 내 말은, 내가 그 선반을 주문했다는 거야…þ

English: Yup.
…last year.þ
What sort of tools do you use?þ
This and that.þ
I could get you a great deal on a tablesaw.þ
Korean: 나는 테이블 톱으로 당신에게 많은 것을 가져다 줄 수 있습니다.þ

English: Nah, she’ll be right mate.þ
Korean: 아냐, 그 사람이 딱 맞는 친구일 거야.þ

English: You ever planning on retiring?þ
Nah, mate.þ
How long you planning on making furniture for then?þ
Long as I can, I reckon.þ
Alright, I have to ask. How do YOU make dinks?þ
Wouldn’t you like to know.þþ
Yeah, I would, I’m in that shop six days a week!þ
Korean: 네, 그럴게요. 저는 일주일에 6일 그 가게에 있어요!þ

English: It’s really rather complicated, I doubt you’d understand.þ
But you don’t sell anything!þ
See? I told you you wouldn’t understand.þ
Korean: 보다? 나는 당신이 이해하지 못할 것이라고 말했습니다.þ

English: How do you keep your suit so neat all the time?þ
Hard work and determination, boy. þ
See, you say that, but I don't see a single crease or stain on it. How hard can you possibly be working?þ
Korean: 보세요, 그렇게 말씀하셨는데, 주름이나 얼룩이 하나도 보이지 않습니다. 얼마나 열심히 일할 수 있나요?þ

English: Oh, I'm not talking about me! I order them express from <SouthCity>. There are extremely hard working folk there. Top of the line.þ
Korean: 아, 나에 대해 말하는 것이 아닙니다! <SouthCity>에서 특급으로 주문해요. 거기에는 매우 열심히 일하는 사람들이 있습니다. 최고의 제품입니다.þ

English: Well, at least you're ordering something yourself then.þ
Korean: 글쎄, 그렇다면 적어도 당신은 스스로 무언가를 주문하고 있는 것입니다.þ

English: Actually, I order somebody to order them. It's all very complicated. I doubt you'd understand.þ
Korean: 사실 저는 누군가에게 주문하라고 주문합니다. 그것은 모두 매우 복잡합니다. 당신이 이해할지 의심스럽습니다.þ

English: Nah mate, I understand just fine, I reckon.þ
Korean: 아뇨, 친구, 충분히 이해한 것 같아요.þ

English: G’day mate. Did those <Dinks> get sent alright?þ
Certainly. It was quite a large sum if I recall.þ
Korean: 틀림없이. 제 기억으로는 꽤 큰 액수였습니다.þ

English: I was just expecting to hear something back. You sure they didn’t get lost on the way?þ
Korean: 나는 단지 뭔가 대답을 듣기를 기대하고 있었습니다. 그 사람들이 도중에 길을 잃지 않은 게 확실해요?þ

English: Do you ever hear anything back?þ
…not really, now that you mention it.þ
I found a shiny disc the other day...
I’ll take it!þ
I kinda like it though…þ
I’ll give you a fair price, can’t get better than that.þ
Korean: 공정한 가격으로 드리겠습니다. 이보다 더 좋을 수는 없습니다.þ

English: I’m gonna keep it. Thanks though!þ
Korean: 나는 그것을 지킬 것이다. 그래도 고마워요!þ

English: I really like the ocean. There's something so calming about it.þ
Korean: 나는 바다를 정말 좋아해요. 그것에 대해 너무 진정되는 뭔가가 있습니다.þ

English: Yeah, I know what you mean. I could listen to it for hours.þ
Korean: 응, 무슨 말인지 알아요. 나는 그것을 몇 시간 동안 들을 수 있었다.þ

English: Me too. I think if I didn't like trading so much, I would've probably been a fisherman.þ
Korean: 저도요. 장사를 별로 안 좋아했다면 아마 어부였을 것 같아요.þ

English: That explains your smell then. To be honest, I was like, seriously going to ask you about it.þ
Korean: 그러면 당신의 냄새가 설명됩니다. 솔직히 말하면, 진지하게 물어볼 것 같았어요.þ

English: Hey! Nothing like a hard day’s yakka to work up a sweat. If I smell bad, I'm proud of it!þ
Korean: 여기요! 땀을 흘리는 데 힘든 하루의 야카만큼 좋은 것은 없습니다. 나쁜 냄새가 나면 자랑스러워요!þ

English: Awwwww. You should feel really proud, then.þ
Korean: 으아아아아. 그렇다면 정말 자랑스러워야 할 것 같습니다.þ

English: I guess we both gave up travelling for <IslandName>, huh?
Korean: 아무래도 우리 둘 다 <IslandName> 여행을 포기한 것 같죠?

English: Yeah. I really like it here.þ
Korean: 응. 나는 여기가 정말 마음에 든다.þ

English: Me too. Don't you miss being out there though?
Korean: 저도요. 그래도 밖에 있는 것이 그리워지지 않나요?

English: A little, but like, it's kinda the whole point, right?þ
Missing things?þ
No, like, travelling. Now it all kinda feels like... like I was just looking for somewhere the whole time. Does that make sense?þ
Korean: 아니, 여행 같은 거요. 이제 모든 것이... 마치 내가 내내 어딘가를 찾고 있었던 것 같은 느낌이 듭니다. 그게 말이 되나요?þ

English: Do you mine much?þ
Korean: 당신은 내 것을 많이 가지고 있습니까?þ

English: Not so much anymoreþ.
Right! Because you didn’t have the right pickaxe, yeah?þ
I don’t have any pickaxes…þ
Well, lucky you came to me!
I think you’d have more customers if you were more confident.þ
Korean: 좀 더 자신감을 가지면 손님이 더 많아질 것 같아요.þ

English: What do you mean?þ
If you speak confidently more people would believe you. Talk loudly and proudly!þ
Korean: 자신있게 말하면 더 많은 사람들이 당신을 믿을 것입니다. 큰 소리로 자랑스럽게 이야기하세요!þ

English: Confident about what?þ
Anything! Believe in yourself!þ
Oh. Okay. Um… I’m confident that your goods are overpriced and break too easily!þ
Korean: 오. 좋아요. 음… 귀하의 제품은 가격이 너무 비싸고 너무 쉽게 부서질 것이라고 확신합니다!þ
