English: Sssshhh! Keep your voice down!þ
There’s something about being in a lot of water that kind of scares meþ
That’s pretty strange. You don’t like the ocean?þ
Nah, not to be in, anyway. I don’t mind looking at it.þ
Korean: 아냐, 어쨌든 거기에 있으면 안 돼. 나는 그것을 보는 것이 마음에 들지 않습니다.þ

English: Why do you think that is? þ
I don’t know, hey. I’ve always been that way, since I was a kid.þ
Korean: 모르겠어요, 안녕. 저는 어렸을 때부터 늘 그랬어요.þ

English: Hmm… did something happen back then? þ
Korean: 흠... 그때 무슨 일이라도 있었나요? þ

English: Nah. Except, if me and my brother ever got into a fight he’d swim out a little and stand on a rock taunting me.
Korean: 아니. 단, 나와 내 동생이 싸우면 조금 헤엄쳐서 바위 위에 서서 나를 조롱하곤 했습니다.

English: How do you sterilise your equipment?þ
Sterra what?þ
I mean, how do you clean everything?þ
Korean: 내 말은, 모든 것을 어떻게 청소합니까?þ

English: Just good old fashioned elbow grease, darlþ
Korean: 그냥 좋은 구식 팔꿈치 그리스야, 달링þ

English: …I feel ill.þ
They are necessary for my work.þ
I just never see you wear them.þ
Korean: 나는 당신이 그것을 입는 것을 본 적이 없습니다.þ

English: You never see me at work.þ
Korean: 당신은 직장에서 나를 본 적이 없습니다.þ

English: You sure they’re just not for show?þ
Korean: 그냥 보여주기 위한 게 아닌 게 확실해요?þ

English: Do you know why the food has these effects?
Korean: 음식이 왜 이런 영향을 미치는지 아시나요?

English: What difference does that make?
To achieve a deeper understanding!
Would that make it taste better?
If you charged an admission, you’d make a killing!þ
But then less people would get to see the exhibits.þ
Korean: 하지만 그러면 전시회를 보는 사람이 줄어들 것입니다.þ

English: You’d make way more <Dinks> though!þ
Korean: 그래도 <Dinks>는 훨씬 더 많이 벌 수 있을 거예요!þ

English: Maybe, but the Museum is for everybody.þ
Are you sure you’re not interested?þ
I’m afraid I really could’t part with any of them.þ
Korean: 나는 정말로 그들 중 누구와도 헤어질 수 없을 것 같습니다.þ

English: You haven’t even heard my prices yet!þ
Korean: 넌 아직 내 가격도 듣지 못했잖아!þ

English: My exhibits really aren’t for sale.þ
Alright mate. Well, I’m here if you need me. Think about it.þ
Korean: 알았어 친구. 글쎄, 내가 필요하면 여기 있어. 생각해 보세요.þ

English: Hey, why don’t you get a shark for the museum?þ
Korean: 야, 박물관에 상어 한 마리 사오는 게 어때?þ

English: To be honest, I, um, don’t think I’d have any other exhibits if I did that.þ
Korean: 솔직히 말하면, 음, 그렇게 하면 다른 전시가 없을 것 같아요.þ

English: Yeah, but, you wouldn’t need them, see? You know why?þ
Korean: 응, 하지만 넌 그런 게 필요하지 않을 거야, 알겠지? 이유를 아시나요?þ

English: Because I’d have a shark?þ
Yeah. You’d have a shark, mate.þ
Thank you. I’ll, um, definitely take that under, um, advisement.þ
Korean: 감사합니다. 나는, 음, 확실히 그 조언을 받아들일 것입니다.þ

English: Mate! A shark! You’d have a bloody shark mate!þ
Korean: 친구! 상어! 당신은 피 묻은 상어 친구를 갖게 될 것입니다!þ

English: Um…þ
Shark!þ
Nice day.þ
Yeah, it is.þ
How are ya?þ
I’m good thanks.þ
Good.þ
It’s nice today.þ
You always say that.
Mornin'
A man of few words.
G’day.þ
Morning.þ
Nice mornin’þ
It is isn’t it?þ
Rain beats the snow.þ
Too right.þ
Rainin’ again.þ
Yeah, I can see that.þ
My knees are playing up again.þ
Why is that?þ
Raining.
My knee is playin’ up again.þ
I have a crystal that might help?þ
I’ll give it a go.þ
How’s the shop going?þ
Great, thanks.þ
Nice to hear.þ
You been busy?þ
You know it! Never enough time in the day.þ
Korean: 당신은 그것을 알고 있습니다! 하루에 시간이 충분하지 않습니다.þ

English: Oath.þ
All these whipper snappers.þ
What about them?þ
Runnin’ around, doing things…þ
I’ll tell you what, they’re very active.þ
Way too fast.þ
Reckon you could make me some new knees?þ
Korean: 나한테 새로운 무릎을 만들어 줄 수 있을 것 같아?þ

English: Most certainly.þ
I’d like some fresh ones, I think.þ
Korean: 내 생각엔 좀 신선한 게 좋을 것 같아.þ

English: The procedure would be excruciating, but certainly possible.þ
Korean: 그 절차는 매우 힘들겠지만, 확실히 가능합니다.þ

English: Maybe I’ll stick with what I’ve got…þ
Korean: 아마도 나는 내가 가진 것을 고수할 것입니다…þ

English: Very well.þ
How’s the lil’ critters?
Good thanks.
That’s good to hear.
How’s yer lil’ critters?þ
They're great!
That’s good to hear.þ
You’re a good bloke..þ
Thanks, mate.þ
Got a good head on your shoulders.þ
How’s it going?þ
Not bad, you?þ
Yeah, can’t complain.
Don’t work too much, alright.þ
Someone has to run the store.þ
Yer store will be fine for a bit.þ
What about everyone here on <IslandName>?þ
What about yer knees? Hmm?.þ
How’s yer brother.þ
Oh, he says he can’t come visit.þ
Why not?þ
He said he had to sell his boat.
You see, back in our day, it was never like that.þ
Korean: 아시다시피, 우리 시대에는 결코 그런 일이 없었습니다.þ

English: Our day?þ
Yeah, there was a bit more patience back then.þ
Korean: 응, 그땐 좀 더 인내심이 있었지.þ

English: I’m much, much younger than you.þ
Whatever you say, mate
They just don’t make ‘em like they used to.þ
Days?þ
Yup. Too long now.
What are you talking about?
You alright?þ
Yeah, just tired.þ
I hear ya.þ
How yer plants treating ya.þ
They are great. They’re always great.þ
That’s real nice, mate.þ
Done any diggin’ lately?þ
A fair bit, yeah.þ
Good on ya.þ
Thanks again for the trim.þ
Don’t mention it.þ
I think it really suits me.þ
Korean: 저한테 정말 잘 맞는 것 같아요.þ

English: Me too, you big softy, it brings out your eyes.þ
Korean: 나도, 너 크고 부드러운, 그것은 당신의 눈을 돋보이게합니다.þ

English: Great day to relax, eh?þ
Speak for yourself, darl.
They are necessary for my work.þ
I just never see you wear them.þ
Korean: 나는 당신이 그것을 입는 것을 본 적이 없습니다.þ

English: You never see me at work.þ
Korean: 당신은 직장에서 나를 본 적이 없습니다.þ

English: You sure they’re just not for show?þ
Korean: 그냥 보여주기 위한 게 아닌 게 확실해요?þ

English: Do you know why the food has these effects?
Korean: 음식이 왜 이런 영향을 미치는지 아시나요?

English: What difference does that make?
To achieve a deeper understanding!
Would that make it taste better?
How’s the paperwork?þ
Oh, fascinating!þ
Never understood it.þ
It’s actually really quite straightforward, it’s all aboutþ...
Never wanted to.þ
…oh.þ
Rotten day.þ
If you say so.þ
What are you so happy about?þ
This conversation will be over soon.þ
Hmph.þ
Whatever you say.þ
Hmph.
Morning.
Hmph.
What did I say?
Hmph.
Alright then.
I wouldn’t pay for weather like this.þ
Korean: 이런 날씨에는 돈을 지불하지 않을 것입니다.þ

English: Luckily it’s free.þ
It’s ridiculous what they are charging.þ
I reckon it seems pretty fair.þ
Korean: 내 생각엔 꽤 공평한 것 같아.þ

English: Out with it. Time is <Dinks>.þ
You were talking to me!þ
So this power can allow you to see the future?þ
Korean: 그렇다면 이 힘으로 미래를 볼 수 있다는 겁니까?þ

English: Sometimes.þ
And how can I access this power?þ
Korean: 그리고 이 힘에 어떻게 접근할 수 있나요?þ

English: You need to feel it, y’know?þ
Hmmm. Kinetic energy of some sort..þ
No. Not at all!þ
What do you mean my coat is drab?þ
You should come and see me.
I am seeing you now and my coat is just as functional as ever.þ
Korean: 지금 뵙고 있는데 제 코트는 예전처럼 기능적이에요.þ

English: I could make you a nicer coat!þ
Korean: 더 멋진 코트를 만들어줄 수 있어요!þ

English: No thank you. This one is adequate.þ
I have an idea for a motorised machine for sewing.
Korean: 나에게 전동 재봉틀에 대한 아이디어가 있어요.

English: Oh wow!
It will pull in a lot of power though.
Oh, but I don’t want it to mess with my chakras.
Korean: 아, 하지만 내 차크라가 엉망이 되는 건 원하지 않아요.

English: I see.
No such license exists.
Well it flamin’ should!þ
That is not for me to decide.þ
Just… be careful, will you?þ
Fine. I will sell only four at a time.þ
Do you remember much about the Shiny Discs?
How old do you think I am?!þ
Honestly, I could not begin to estimate.þ
Korean: 솔직히 나는 추정을 시작할 수 없었습니다.þ

English: Well it was before my time, I’ll tell you what!þ
Korean: 글쎄요, 제 때가 오기 전이었는데, 그걸 말씀드릴게요!þ

English: Did your father ever venture into the deep mines?þ
Korean: 당신의 아버지는 깊은 광산에 들어가 본 적이 있나요?þ

English: Oh, my father went everywhere, I’ll tell you what!þ
Korean: 아, 아버지는 어디든 가셨는데 그게 뭔지 말씀 드리겠습니다!þ

English: Then perhaps you would answer a few questions?þ
Korean: 그렇다면 몇 가지 질문에 답해 주시겠습니까?þ

English: Sure, how long you got?þ
Have you performed any experiments on your creatures?þ
Korean: 당신의 생물에 대한 실험을 수행한 적이 있습니까?þ

English: Um… no? What?þ
You could make them stronger, faster, better!þ
Korean: 당신은 그들을 더 강하고, 더 빠르고, 더 좋게 만들 수 있습니다!þ

English: I think they’re fine just the way they are, thanks.þ
Korean: 내 생각에는 그 사람들이 있는 그대로 괜찮은 것 같아요. 고마워요.þ

English: But with the right upgradesþ...
I heard you, I’m just not interested, mate.þ
Korean: 들었어, 난 그냥 관심이 없어, 친구.þ

English: Think of the possibilities!þ
Just leave nature alone, yeah?þ
Does the smell not bother you?þ
A little, but you’re not that bad, mate!þ
Korean: 조금, 하지만 그렇게 나쁘지는 않잖아, 친구!þ

English: I am speaking of your creatures.þ
Korean: 나는 당신의 피조물에 대해 말하고 있습니다.þ

English: Oh, maybe. Some of them have really sensitive noses!þ
Korean: 아, 어쩌면. 그들 중 일부는 정말 민감한 코를 가지고 있습니다!þ

English: Your tools are inferior to anything I can craft.þ
Korean: 당신의 도구는 내가 만들 수 있는 어떤 도구보다 열등합니다.þ

English: My tools are much cheaper though.þ
Yes they are.þ
But, they get the job done!þ
Yes they do. Slowly.þ
Why do I talk to you…þ
Korean: 내가 왜 너한테 말을 하는 거지...þ

English: Are you interested in stocking some of my inventions?
Korean: 내 발명품 중 일부를 구입하는 데 관심이 있습니까?

English: That sounds great!
But I need to run my shop!þ
Then this business proposal is now moot.
Korean: 그렇다면 이 사업 제안은 이제 논란의 여지가 있습니다.

English: Well, I have to send a lot back home…þ
I suppose someone back in South City is doing research for you?þ
Korean: South City에 있는 누군가가 당신을 위해 연구를 하고 있는 것 같은데요?þ

English: You could say that…þ
Then I hope you share what you have learnt soon.þ
Korean: 그렇다면 곧 여러분이 배운 내용을 공유하길 바랍니다.þ

English: How would I do that?þ
Perhaps you could splice the seeds?þ
I could never do that!þ
I do not understand…þ
It would hurt the seeds!þ
I require your assistance.þ
Sure!
Please stop bothering me when I am trying to work.þ
Korean: 제가 일하려고 할 때 저를 괴롭히지 마세요.þ

English: I thought I was helping…þ
You were not.þ
What is your favourite plant?þ
Like, it’s hard to pick one type…þ
Type? I want to see the specific plant.þ
I, like, love them all equally.þ
Impossible.þ
Have you ever considered a different field?þ
Korean: 다른 분야를 생각해 본 적 있나요?þ

English: Further north, you mean?þ
I mean some other occupation.þ
Oh. All the time! But what about my customers?þ
Korean: 오. 항상! 하지만 내 고객은 어떻습니까?þ

English: I believe they would survive.þ
I spent yesterday arranging my instruments.þ
Is that why you cancelled your appointment?þ
I did not make an appointment.þ
I’m free tomorrow, my client list is pretty shortþ.
Korean: 내일 한가해요. 제 고객 목록이 꽤 짧거든요þ.

English: Of that, I am certain.þ
Have you considered adding restraints to your chair?þ
Korean: 의자에 고정 장치를 추가하는 것을 고려해 보셨나요?þ

English: I don’t think it’s going to go anywhereþ.
I was thinking of your customersþ.
Oh, might be an idea, then. Safety first!þ
Korean: 아, 그렇다면 좋은 생각이겠네요. 안전 제일!þ

English: How do you sterilise your equipment?þ
Sterra what?þ
I mean, how do you clean everything?þ
Korean: 내 말은, 모든 것을 어떻게 청소합니까?þ

English: Just good old fashioned elbow grease, darlþ
Korean: 그냥 좋은 구식 팔꿈치 그리스야, 달링þ

English: …I feel ill.þ
They are necessary for my work.þ
I just never see you wear them.þ
Korean: 나는 당신이 그것을 입는 것을 본 적이 없습니다.þ

English: You never see me at work.þ
Korean: 당신은 직장에서 나를 본 적이 없습니다.þ

English: You sure they’re just not for show?þ
Korean: 그냥 보여주기 위한 게 아닌 게 확실해요?þ

English: Do you know why the food has these effects?
Korean: 음식이 왜 이런 영향을 미치는지 아시나요?

English: What difference does that make?
To achieve a deeper understanding!
Would that make it taste better?
What will you do when your collection is complete?þ
Categorization and filing!þ
Of course, but what then?þ
Re-categorization and re-filing!þ
Do you dissect your specimens?þ
Oh, no! I could never do that!þ
Korean: 안 돼! 난 절대 그럴 수 없어!þ

English: Then you are missing out on so much knowledge!þ
Korean: 그렇다면 당신은 너무 많은 지식을 놓치고 있는 것입니다!þ

English: I think um, maybe that’s okay?þ
Korean: 내 생각엔 음, 어쩌면 괜찮은 것 같아?þ

English: How did you collect all of your specimens?þ
Oh! <PlayerName> has been helping.þ
What a remarkable coincidence.þ
Yeah, they’ve been really helpful!þ
Today's going quick!
Not quick enough.
Lovely weather we're having.
Too right.
Another begining to a beautiful day!
I guess you could say that.
Feeling good this morning?
Nothing to complain about.
It's just such a pretty morning.
Oh, it is.
Wet enough for you?
You always say that.
This rain won't let up.
Why are you always wandering around in it?
Korean: 너는 왜 항상 그 안에서 헤매고 있는 걸까?

English: This rain is great for my plants.
Korean: 이 비는 내 식물에 아주 좋습니다.

English: Happy to hear that.
I like, love your store.þ
Thanks, but she’s taken.þ
No, I mean, I love your fashion!þ
Korean: 아니, 내 말은, 난 네 패션이 마음에 든다는 거야!þ

English: So does she, y’know?þ
Where do you come up with your ideas?þ
You just have to feel them, y’know?þ
Like, kinda?þ
So take that “kinda”, and just run with it!
I’m so exhausted from today.þ
Oh, you should meditate more.þ
That’s like, doing nothing, right?þ
Korean: 그건 아무것도 안 하는 것과 같죠?þ

English: Sort of, but better, y’know?
It’s pretty crazy you managed to make this happen.þ
Korean: 당신이 이런 일이 일어나도록 관리했다는 것은 정말 미친 일입니다.þ

English: Nothing crazy about it, just one foot in front of the other.þ
Korean: 그것에 대해 미친 것은 없습니다. 단지 한 발이 다른 발 앞에 있습니다.þ

English: Still, you like, started it all!þ
Korean: 그래도 당신이 좋아하는 모든 것을 시작했습니다!þ

English: It’s like my Dad used to say. Get it done!
Korean: 우리 아빠가 늘 말씀하셨던 것과 같아요. 완료하세요!

English: So how old are you? Like, really?þ
I can’t answer that!þ
Oh, you poor thing. I guess your memory must be going…þ
Korean: 아, 불쌍한 것. 아무래도 기억이 가물가물할 것 같은데...þ

English: What?! No! I mean, it’s none of your bloody business!þ
Korean: 무엇?! 아니요! 내 말은, 그건 당신이 할 일이 아니야!þ

English: Hey, you’ve got some real pep in your step today!þ
Thanks dear. I’ve been doing my morning stretches every day this week.þ
Korean: 고마워요. 이번주에는 매일 아침 스트레칭을 했어요.þ

English: Well, keep at it, because it’s really working for you. You look amazing!þ
Korean: 글쎄요, 계속하세요. 정말 효과가 있으니까요. 정말 대단해 보여요!þ

English: I sure will. So, which licences did you want to talk about?þ
Korean: 꼭 그럴 거예요. 그렇다면 어떤 라이선스에 대해 이야기하고 싶으신가요?þ

English: How did you know I like, wanted something?þ
Korean: 내가 뭔가를 좋아하고 원하는 걸 어떻게 알았나요?þ

English: You couldn’t be more obvious with a sign around your neck, I tell you what!þ
Korean: 목 주위에 표시가 있으면 더 분명해질 수 없습니다.þ

English: Do you like, always speak your mind?þ
Korean: 당신은 항상 당신의 마음을 말하는 것을 좋아합니까?þ

English: Approximately five percent of it, yes.þ
What’s in the rest?þ
It is beyond words.þ
Oh, so like, numbers and stuff?þ
Do you ever miss South City?þ
Only the Blobfish. þ
I heard they were like, completely bland and flavourlessþ.
Precisely. They were not distracting.þ
Korean: 정확하게. 그들은 주의를 산만하게 하지 않았습니다.þ

English: I think you’d really enjoy gardeningþ.
Korean: 내 생각엔 너는 정원 가꾸기를 정말 좋아할 것 같아þ.

English: Why do you say that?þ
It can be really, like, chill?þ
I am quite “chill” enough.þ
Um… if you say so…þ
I love how much attention you give to your critters.þ
Korean: 나는 당신이 동물에게 얼마나 많은 관심을 기울이는지 좋아합니다.þ

English: They sure deserve it. We’re lucky to have them around.þþ
Korean: 그들은 확실히 그럴 자격이 있습니다. 우리 주변에 그런 사람들이 있다는 것은 행운입니다.þþ

English: Awwww, that’s so sweet!þ
Really though, I mean, how lucky are we? Unreal!þ
Korean: 그런데 정말로, 내 말은, 우리는 얼마나 운이 좋은 걸까요? 언리얼!þ

English: Croco’s are like, so scary!þ
Nah, they’re just misunderstood.þ
Korean: 아니, 그들은 단지 오해를 받고 있을 뿐입니다.þ

English: All those teeth, and they’re not afraid to use them!þ
Korean: 그 많은 이빨들, 그들은 그것을 사용하는 것을 두려워하지 않습니다!þ

English: They just like to keep to themselves, I reckon.þ
Korean: 내 생각에는 그들은 단지 자기들끼리만 있기를 좋아하는 것 같다.þ

English: Do the Wary Mus scare you?þ
Oh, those critters can sure run!þ
Korean: 아, 그 동물들은 확실히 달릴 수 있어요!þ

English: I know, right? It’s like, calm down guys, I was leaving!þ
Korean: 나도 알아, 그렇지? 진정하세요 여러분, 제가 떠날 예정이었습니다!þ

English: Such amazing critters, and the size of those eggs!þ
Korean: 정말 놀라운 동물들과 그 알의 크기!þ

English: Do you miss your family a lot?þ
I still keep in touch with my brother.þ
That’s so sweet.þ
You haven’t seen your family?þ
Not for a while… it’s complicated.þ
I don’t think I really need that?þ
Korean: 나한테는 그게 별로 필요 없을 것 같은데?þ

English: It’s top of the line, it’ll save you heaps of time!þ
Korean: 최고 수준이므로 시간을 많이 절약할 수 있습니다!þ

English: But like, I don’t really fish?þ
Korean: 그런데 제가 낚시를 별로 안 하는 걸까요?þ

English: Well, why not start today?
Korean: 자, 오늘부터 시작해 보는 건 어떨까요?

English: Are your bananas ethically sourced?þ
What? I don’t think the trees mindþ.þ
Korean: 무엇? 나무는 별로 신경쓰지 않는 것 같아요þ.þ

English: Are they like, sustainable trees?þ
They haven’t fallen over yet!þ
I love your work. It’s a shame about the trees though.þ
Korean: 나는 당신의 일을 사랑합니다. 그래도 나무가 아쉽네요.þ

English: Trees? Nah, I only use logs and planks.þ
Korean: 나무? 아뇨, 저는 통나무와 판자만 사용해요.þ

English: Yeah but, they used to be trees, right?þ
Well, we all gotta start somewhere.
Korean: 글쎄, 우리 모두 어딘가에서 시작해야 해.

English: Where’d you learn to make things?þ
Here and there.þ
Oh, you like, taught yourself?þ
Nah, I reckon the splinters taught me pretty well.þ
Korean: 아니, 파편이 나에게 꽤 잘 가르쳐 준 것 같아요.þ

English: You seem like, really sad sometimes.þ
Korean: 당신은 가끔 정말 슬픈 것 같아요.þ

English: Just me face, I reckon.þ
Korean: 내 생각엔 그냥 내 얼굴인 것 같아.þ

English: So really you’re secretly feelin’ bonza?þ
Korean: 그럼 정말 당신은 비밀리에 기분이 좋아졌나요?þ

English: I get by, yeah.þ
I’m gonna take that as a yesþ.
Righto.þ
I just think like, money’s not everything?þ
Korean: 그냥 돈이 전부는 아닌 것 같아요?þ

English: That’s preposterous!þ
There’s like, other things out there…þ
And only one thing that matters!þ
You could be a little nicer sometimes…þ
Nicer? Where does nice get anybody?þ
Korean: 더 좋은가요? 좋은 사람은 어디서 얻나요?þ

English: It doesn’t like, cost anything to be nice.þ
Korean: 마음에 들지 않습니다. 친절하려면 비용이 많이 듭니다.þ

English: Hmph. It doesn’t pay anything either!þ
Is that like, an old person thing?þ
Old?! I’m in the prime of my life!þ
Korean: 오래된?! 나는 내 인생의 전성기에 있어요!þ

English: Oh! I didn’t mean to offend you!þ
Korean: 오! 당신을 화나게 하려는 의도는 아니었어요!þ

English: Hmph.
Have you ever used a scythe?þ
Who told you that?!þ
N-n-nobody, I just, like, wheat is like hair, right?þ
Korean: 아-아-아무도, 난 그냥 밀이 머리카락이랑 비슷하지 않나?þ

English: You’d think so…þ
Um…þ
You’d be wrong.þ
Oh…
So like, how’s the salon thing going?þ
A little quiet actually, lately. Were you thinking of popping in?þ
Korean: 사실 최근에는 좀 조용했어요. 혹시 튀어나올 생각이었어?þ

English: No way! Um, I mean, I was thinking of growing it out a little.þ
Korean: 안 돼요! 음, 좀 더 키워볼까 생각하고 있었거든요.þ

English: Right, yeah, of course. If you change your mind though, you know where to find me.þ
Korean: 그렇죠, 물론이죠. 그래도 마음이 바뀌면 나를 어디서 찾을 수 있는지 알 수 있을 거예요.þ

English: Totally. Awesome.þ
So I heard you used to mine?þ
Yeah. Back in <SouthCity> for a while.þ
I bet things can get pretty freaky-deaky when you get super deep down, huh?þ
Korean: 당신이 아주 깊이 들어가면 상황이 꽤 이상해질 수 있을 것 같아요, 그렇죠?þ

English: Definitely. I think you’d like it though.þ
What makes you say that?þ
There’s all sorts of weird and whacky plants down there! One of them even tried to eat me!þ
Korean: 거기에는 온갖 종류의 이상하고 별난 식물들이 있어요! 그 중 한 명은 나를 잡아먹으려고까지 했어요!þ

English: Oh wow! Now those? Those I have to see. Like, for reals.
Korean: 아 와! 이제 그거요? 내가 봐야 할 것들. 진짜로요.

English: Have you ever like, tried going vegan?þ
Korean: 완전 채식을 시도해 본 적이 있나요?þ

English: I eat mostly wheat, I reckon.þ
Korean: 나는 주로 밀을 먹는 것 같아요.þ

English: Oh, yeah?
Yeah, lotta pastry in me meat pies!
Korean: 그래, 고기 파이에 페이스트리가 잔뜩 들어있어!

English: Why do you only get one of each?þ
One is all you need for the records.þ
Don’t they like, get lonely?þ
Oh! Um. I hope not?
I think I’d be lonely in a cage by myselfþ.
Korean: 새장 속에 혼자 있으면 외로울 것 같아þ.

English: They’re not by themselves! They have tons of friends!þ
Korean: 그들은 그 자체가 아닙니다! 그들은 수많은 친구를 가지고 있습니다!þ

English: Yeah, but they’re all different types…þ
So are we, and we’re friends, right?þ
Oh yeah! I guess you’re right.
Korean: 아 그래! 당신 말이 맞는 것 같아요.

English: I’ve been loving your museum lately!þ
Korean: 나는 요즘 당신의 박물관을 정말 좋아해요!þ

English: Oh, um, thank you.þ
It’s like, so nice to appreciate all those creepy-crawlies when they’re not trying to eat my crops.þ
Korean: 내 농작물을 먹으려 하지 않을 때 그 소름 끼치는 벌레들에게 감사하는 것은 정말 좋은 일입니다.þ

English: Why would they be doing that?þ
I guess I can’t blame them. Everything’s gotta eat something!þ
Korean: 그들을 비난할 수는 없을 것 같아요. 뭐든지 뭔가를 먹어야 해!þ

English: Oh. Um. Are you sure? I’ve made a terrible mistake.þ
Korean: 오. 음. 확실합니까? 나는 끔찍한 실수를 저질렀습니다.þ

English: You’re so funny, Teddy.þ
Phew.
Safe.
Is it gone?
Am I safe?
Woah.
That was close!
I’m feeling great today!þ
That’s nice.þ
You reckon you will come visit me for a snip?þ
Korean: 당신은 한 입 먹으러 나를 방문할 것이라고 생각합니까?þ

English: Oh… I don’t know…þ
How’s your day going?þ
Can’t complain.þ
You're looking fresh today!
Thank you!
Hope you're having a good morning.
I am, thanks.
Beautiful morning, right?þ
Sure is!
This weather is great for your hair.þ
Oh, really?þ
You should check out my mirror sometime.þ
What do you mean?
It’s getting late.þ
Not too late, though.þ
Do you need any help around your shop?þ
No thanks. Most of the time I’m good?þ
I know my way around a pair of scissors, if that helpsþ
Korean: 도움이 된다면 가위를 사용하는 방법을 알아요þ

English: Yeah, but then how would I get all this burning rage out of me, y’know?þ
Korean: 응, 그런데 그러면 이 타오르는 분노를 어떻게 없애버릴 수 있겠어?þ

English: What?
Oh, nothing. Do you meditate?þ
You’re really out there sometimes.þ
Thank you.þ
I like it though. It’s like you, um, see more?þ
Korean: 그래도 마음에 든다. 너랑 비슷해, 음, 더 볼래?þ

English: I do.þ
How’s your world going?þ
Wow. That’s a big question.þ
Is it?þ
Yeah… I’m not sure I can answer it, y’know?þ
Korean: 응... 내가 대답할 수 있을지 모르겠어, 알지?þ

English: Um… sorry…þ
No, that’s okay. It’s just… wow. What a big question?þ
Korean: 아니요, 괜찮습니다. 그냥… 와. 얼마나 큰 질문입니까?þ

English: How did you get so, um, confident?þ
Korean: 어떻게 그렇게, 음, 자신감을 가지게 됐나요?þ

English: I’d hardly say that!þ
You are! You always seem to know what you’re doing.þ
Korean: 당신은! 당신은 항상 자신이 무엇을 하고 있는지 알고 있는 것 같습니다.þ

English: Somebody’s gotta make a decision eventually, or else nothing gets done!þ
Korean: 누군가는 결국 결정을 내려야 합니다. 그렇지 않으면 아무 일도 일어나지 않습니다!þ

English: See, you said that with such confidence!
Hey, I don’t need to renew my licence anytime soon do I?þ
Korean: 안녕하세요, 조만간 면허증을 갱신할 필요가 없겠죠?þ

English: Nah, you’re all up to date, I reckon.þ
Korean: 아뇨, 제 생각에는 모두 최신 상태이군요.þ

English: Phew. I was really worried because I’ve been failing the test.þ
Korean: 휴. 시험에 떨어졌기 때문에 정말 걱정했어요.þ

English: Test? You’ve been doing a test?þ
Yeah! Just at home with some of my models.þ
Korean: 응! 내 모델 몇 명과 함께 집에 있어요.þ

English: I’ve never seen any models at your place, I’ll tell you what!þ
Korean: 나는 당신 집에서 어떤 모델도 본 적이 없습니다. 말씀 드리겠습니다!þ

English: Yeah… I had to bury them.þ
I've use to see these strange metal wrecks down in the mines.þ
Korean: 나는 광산에서 이런 이상한 금속 잔해를 본 적이 있습니다.þ

English: Yeah, there’s all sorts down there.þ
What did you used to use them for?þ
That’s long before my time, love. They were old back then too.þ
Korean: 그건 내 시간보다 훨씬 전이야, 얘야. 그때도 그 분들도 늙었거든요.þ

English: Do you ever get lost in your thoughts?þ
Korean: 당신은 당신의 생각에 길을 잃은 적이 있습니까?þ

English: I do not understand. Do you often get lost at home?þ
Korean: 이해가 안 돼요. 집에서 자주 길을 잃나요?þ

English: Um… sometimes…þ
This information does not surprise me.þ
Why do you think everything went South?þ
Korean: 왜 모든 것이 남쪽으로 갔다고 생각합니까?þ

English: I still do not completely know.þ
Oh, so I guess you don’t know everything after all, huh?þ
Korean: 아, 결국 당신은 모든 것을 모르는 것 같군요?þ

English: …Not yet.
You can be a real jerk sometimes, Franklyn.þ
Korean: 가끔은 진짜 바보가 될 수도 있어요, 프랭클린.þ

English: Preposterous, I move the same speed as the rest of you, physically.þ
Korean: 터무니없네요. 저는 육체적으로 여러분과 같은 속도로 움직입니다.þ

English: I’m saying you can be really rude!þ
I suppose I just do not consider your “feelings”
Korean: 나는 단지 당신의 "감정"을 고려하지 않는 것 같아요

English: Well, do you think you could try a little?
Korean: 글쎄요, 조금 시도해 볼 수 있을까요?

English: Absolutely. I am certain that I could try.
Korean: 전적으로. 나는 시도해 볼 수 있다고 확신합니다.

English: Alright! That was easy.
I did not say that I was going to.
Korean: 나는 내가 갈 것이라고 말하지 않았다.

English: How did you figure out what you wanna do for a living?þ
Korean: 당신이 먹고 싶은 일이 무엇인지 어떻게 알았나요?þ

English: Me? It just kinda came to me, I guess.þ
Korean: 나? 그냥 나에게 다가온 것 같아요.þ

English: You think that’ll happen for me?þ
Korean: 나한테 그런 일이 일어날 것 같아?þ

English: Sure! I reckon it just takes a bit of time.þ
Korean: 확신하는! 시간이 좀 걸릴 뿐이라고 생각해요.þ

English: How much time?þ
How long’s a piece of string?
Do you have a favourite critter?þ
Nah. There’s just too many, and they’re all great at something.þ
Korean: 아니. 너무 많아서 모두 뭔가를 잘합니다.þ

English: C’mon, you can tell me if you do.þ
Well… I used to have a pet called Steve.þ
What kind of critter was it?þ
It was caring soul. Real gentle, but a huge personality.þ
Korean: 배려하는 마음이었습니다. 진짜 온화하지만 성격이 엄청나다.þ

English: I mean, um, what type?þ
I think it was a Pisces? Great little critter, couldn’t do enough for you.þ
Korean: 물고기자리였던 것 같은데? 훌륭하고 작은 동물, 당신을 위해 충분히 할 수 없었습니다.þ

English: How do have so much energy all the time?þ
Korean: 어떻게 항상 그렇게 많은 에너지를 가지고 있습니까?þ

English: A good night's rest and a morning walk does the trick, I reckon.þ
Korean: 밤에 잘 쉬고 아침에 산책을 하면 효과가 있을 것 같아요.þ

English: I try that, but I’m still so sleepy by lunchtime.þ
Korean: 그렇게 해 보지만 점심시간이 되어도 여전히 너무 졸립니다.þ

English: That’s why they invented naps, mate!þ
Korean: 그래서 그들이 낮잠을 발명한 거야, 친구!þ

English: Do you like your job?þ
Trading? Of course! I bloody love it!þ
You ever try to do something different?þ
Korean: 뭔가 다른 것을 시도해 본 적 있나요?þ

English: Why would I when it’s my favourite thing?þ
Korean: 내가 가장 좋아하는 일인데 왜 그럴까요?þ

English: Yeah, but how do you know that if you’ve never tried anything else?þ
Korean: 네, 하지만 다른 것을 시도해 본 적이 없다면 어떻게 알 수 있나요?þ

English: It’s Jack you’re thinking of.þ
Who’s Jack?þ
That guy with all the trades, mate. I’m a John of one.þ
Korean: 그 사람은 모든 거래를 가지고 있습니다. 친구. 저는 John 중 하나입니다.þ

English: You got any good deals coming up?þ
All my deals are great, mate.þ
Thinking of doing a sale anytime soon?þ
Sale?! No way! Gross!þ
I don’t know how you keep your shop open so late.þ
Korean: 어떻게 그렇게 늦게까지 가게를 열었는지 모르겠어요.þ

English: What can I say? You’ve got to give the people what they want.þ
Korean: 내가 무엇을 말할 수 있습니까? 사람들이 원하는 것을 주어야 합니다.þ

English: Maybe… but I get so tired after my shifts.þ
Korean: 어쩌면… 하지만 교대근무 후에는 너무 피곤해요.þ

English: I’ve got some Bush Limes that’ll help keep you going.þ
Korean: 계속해서 활동하는 데 도움이 될 부시 라임을 준비했습니다.þ

English: Maybe I’ll stop by.þ
Well, get in quick, I’ve got limited stock.þ
Korean: 자, 빨리 오세요. 재고가 한정되어 있습니다.þ

English: Your regular visits mean a lot to meþ.
Korean: 귀하의 정기적인 방문은 나에게 큰 의미가 있습니다þ.

English: They’re the highlight of my weekþ
Are you sure you like it styled like that?þ
You’re the expert mate, I trust you.
You got much going on later?þ
Oh, you know. Bit of this, bit of that.þ
Korean: 아, 아시죠? 이것 좀, 그거 좀.þ

English: Pretty full schedule?þ
Yup.þ
Maybe some other time then.þ
How’s that new chair coming along?þ
Korean: 그 새 의자는 잘 되어가고 있나요?þ

English: She’s a goodun.þ
Nice spin to it?þ
Mate, it spins like a dream.þ
I can’t wait! The spin is half the fun of getting a haircut!þ
Korean: 너무 기대돼요! 회전은 머리를 자르는 재미의 절반입니다!þ

English: My mum was a lot like you, Milburn.þ
Korean: 우리 엄마는 당신과 많이 닮았어요, 밀번.þ

English: Strong? Athletic? Young?þ
…nothing. I’m sorry. Forget it
No, I mean, she took one thing and made it her whole personality…þ
Korean: 아니, 내 말은, 그녀는 한 가지를 가져다가 그것을 자신의 성격 전체로 삼았다는 것입니다…þ

English: What sort of thing?þ.þ
Well, it kinda doesn’t matter, right? With you, it’s <Dinks>.þ
Korean: 뭐, 별 상관은 없겠죠? 여러분과 함께 <딩크스>입니다.þ

English: You’re saying <Dinks> don’t matter?!þ
I’m saying NOTHING does! Or at least it shouldn’t! It shouldn’t consume you!þ
Korean: 나는 아무것도하지 않는다고 말하고 있습니다! 아니면 적어도 그렇게해서는 안됩니다! 그것은 당신을 소비해서는 안됩니다!þ

English: My dear, <Dinks> matter the most!þ
WELL THEY SHOULDN’T MATTER MORE THAN YOUR FAMILY!!!þ
Korean: 글쎄, 그들은 당신의 가족보다 더 중요하지 않아야 합니다!!!þ

English: W-w-w-what was that?þ
What’s with the glass screen in your bank?þ
For security, of course.þ
Yeah, but, you’ve um, got a safe too, right?þ
Korean: 응, 그런데 너, 음, 금고도 있잖아, 그렇지?þ

English: Certainly.  You can never be too careful.þ
Korean: 틀림없이.  결코 너무 조심할 수는 없습니다.þ

English: How’s your week been so far?þ
Marvellous. I spent a lot of it counting.þ
Korean: 기이. 나는 그것을 계산하는 데 많은 시간을 보냈습니다.þ

English: Counting? What did you get up to?þ
It’s not about the destination. With <Dinks> it’s about the journey.þ
Korean: 목적지에 관한 것이 아닙니다. <Dinks>는 여행에 관한 것입니다.þ

English: I love your hair, is that colour natural?þ
Korean: 머리가 너무 맘에 드는데요, 그 색이 자연스럽나요?þ

English: Of course! I’d never put chemicals in my hair.þ
Korean: 물론! 나는 결코 머리에 화학 물질을 넣지 않았습니다.þ

English: I don’t think I’d be able to pull that look off.þ
Korean: 그 표정을 지울 수 없을 것 같아요.þ

English: You don’t need to, you’ve got your own thing going, I like it.þ
Korean: 그럴 필요는 없어요. 당신만의 일이 있으니까요. 좋아요.þ

English: Oh, hey! You used to live on an airship, right?þ
Korean: 아, 안녕! 당신은 비행선에서 살았죠, 그렇죠?þ

English: Yeah, for like, years!þ
So you must know a bit about fixing machines and stuff?þ
Korean: 그러면 당신은 기계나 물건을 고치는 것에 대해 조금 알아야 합니까?þ

English: Sort of… like… if it was broke we’d hit it a bunch I guess. Why?þ
Korean: 일종의... 마치... 망가지면 우리는 많이 쳤을 것 같아요. 왜?þ

English: I think my scissors are broken.þ
Weird. What’s wrong with them?þ
I don’t know. I’m not down with all the tech lingo. They just don’t cut right.þ
Korean: 모르겠습니다. 나는 모든 기술 용어에 만족하지 않습니다. 그들은 단지 제대로 자르지 않습니다.þ

English: Yeah… I think that’s beyond my like, skillset?þ
Korean: 응... 그건 내 능력을 넘어서는 것 같은데?þ

English: I really like your attitude.þ
Thanks! I try and like, stay positive, I guess?þ
Korean: 감사해요! 나는 긍정적인 태도를 유지하려고 노력합니다.þ

English: Yeah, that’s it. It’s infectiousþ
That sounds terrible!þ
No no no, in a good way!þ
Alright. Right on!þ
Yeahþ
How do you sterilise your equipment?þ
Sterra what?þ
I mean, how do you clean everything?þ
Korean: 내 말은, 모든 것을 어떻게 청소합니까?þ

English: Just good old fashioned elbow grease, darlþ
Korean: 그냥 좋은 구식 팔꿈치 그리스야, 달링þ

English: …I feel ill.þ
They are necessary for my work.þ
I just never see you wear them.þ
Korean: 나는 당신이 그것을 입는 것을 본 적이 없습니다.þ

English: You never see me at work.þ
Korean: 당신은 직장에서 나를 본 적이 없습니다.þ

English: You sure they’re just not for show?þ
Korean: 그냥 보여주기 위한 게 아닌 게 확실해요?þ

English: Do you know why the food has these effects?
Korean: 음식이 왜 이런 영향을 미치는지 아시나요?

English: What difference does that make?
To achieve a deeper understanding!
Would that make it taste better?
How was yesterday?þ
Peaceful. It was so quiet at the museum.þ
Did you catch up on all your paperwork?þ
I’m, um, never behind on paperwork.þ
Korean: 저는, 음, 서류 작업에 뒤처진 적이 없어요.þ

English: Well did it catch up with you?þ
It can sure try!þ
More paperwork yesterday?þ
I wish! No, I had a fun day anyway though!þ
Korean: 나는 바란다! 아니 그래도 오늘 하루는 즐거웠어요!þ

English: Oh cool, what did you do?þ
Korean: 오 멋지다, 무슨 짓을 한 거야?þ

English: I stomped past all the exhibits in slow motion!þ
Korean: 나는 슬로우모션으로 모든 전시품을 쿵쿵거리며 지나갔습니다!þ

English: Um…?þ
Yeah! I felt like a dinosaur! Raaarrghh!þ
What’s a dinosaur?þ
I’m not sure. I guess you had to be there…þ
Korean: 잘 모르겠습니다. 아무래도 당신이 거기 있었어야 했을 것 같은데...þ

English: You should get some of those Jelly Fish in your museum!þ
Korean: 박물관에 있는 해파리 중 일부를 구입해야 합니다!þ

English: I thought about it, but, I really don’t trust the way they move.þ
Korean: 생각해봤는데, 움직이는 방식이 정말 신뢰가 안 가요.þ

English: Really? I find it super relaxing.þ
Korean: 정말? 나는 그것이 매우 편안하다고 생각합니다.þ

English: Yeah, that’s how they get you. You think ‘Oh, that’s cute’þ
Korean: 응, 그게 널 잡는 방법이야. '아, 그거 귀엽다'라고 생각하시죠?þ

English: Awwww.þ
Then, all of a sudden, BAM! þ
Oh!þ
That’s right. One-way ticket to sting-town. It’s chaos! þ
Korean: 좋아요. 스팅타운으로 가는 편도 티켓입니다. 혼돈이야! þ

English: They couldn’t get you from behind the glass though, could they?þ
Korean: 하지만 그들은 유리 뒤에서 당신을 데려올 수는 없었죠, 그렇죠?þ

English: Maybe, maybe not. I’m not taking any chances.þ
Korean: 어쩌면 아닐 수도 있습니다. 나는 어떤 위험도 감수하지 않습니다.þ

English: Happy Sky Fest!
Happy Sky Fest, {0}
Have a great Sky Fest!
My fish are going crazy!þ
Why is that?þ
They know it’s raining.þ
Korean: 그들은 비가 온다는 것을 알고 있습니다.þ

English: But what if the museum floods?þ
Korean: 하지만 박물관에 홍수가 나면 어떻게 될까요?þ

English: It’s not that much rain, mate.þ
Not all day.þ
I miss standing at my desk.þ
Korean: 책상 앞에 서 있는 게 그리워요.þ

English: You did that all day.þ
Not all day.þ
Do you think the museum is still nice and organised?þ
Korean: 박물관이 여전히 멋지고 잘 정돈되어 있다고 생각하시나요?þ

English: I’m sure it’s fine.þ
Maybe I should quickly go and check?þ
NO! Stay here, it’s fine.þ
So this power can allow you to see the future?þ
Korean: 그렇다면 이 힘으로 미래를 볼 수 있다는 겁니까?þ

English: Sometimes.þ
And how can I access this power?þ
Korean: 그리고 이 힘에 어떻게 접근할 수 있나요?þ

English: You need to feel it, y’know?þ
Hmmm. Kinetic energy of some sort..þ
No. Not at all!þ
What do you mean my coat is drab?þ
You should come and see me.
I am seeing you now and my coat is just as functional as ever.þ
Korean: 지금 뵙고 있는데 제 코트는 예전처럼 기능적이에요.þ

English: I could make you a nicer coat!þ
Korean: 더 멋진 코트를 만들어줄 수 있어요!þ

English: No thank you. This one is adequate.þ
I have an idea for a motorised machine for sewing.
Korean: 나에게 전동 재봉틀에 대한 아이디어가 있어요.

English: Oh wow!
It will pull in a lot of power though.
Oh, but I don’t want it to mess with my chakras.
Korean: 아, 하지만 내 차크라가 엉망이 되는 건 원하지 않아요.

English: I see.
No such license exists.
Well it flamin’ should!þ
That is not for me to decide.þ
Just… be careful, will you?þ
Fine. I will sell only four at a time.þ
Do you remember much about the Shiny Discs?
How old do you think I am?!þ
Honestly, I could not begin to estimate.þ
Korean: 솔직히 나는 추정을 시작할 수 없었습니다.þ

English: Well it was before my time, I’ll tell you what!þ
Korean: 글쎄요, 제 때가 오기 전이었는데, 그걸 말씀드릴게요!þ

English: Did your father ever venture into the deep mines?þ
Korean: 당신의 아버지는 깊은 광산에 들어가 본 적이 있나요?þ

English: Oh, my father went everywhere, I’ll tell you what!þ
Korean: 아, 아버지는 어디든 가셨는데 그게 뭔지 말씀 드리겠습니다!þ

English: Then perhaps you would answer a few questions?þ
Korean: 그렇다면 몇 가지 질문에 답해 주시겠습니까?þ

English: Sure, how long you got?þ
Have you performed any experiments on your creatures?þ
Korean: 당신의 생물에 대한 실험을 수행한 적이 있습니까?þ

English: Um… no? What?þ
You could make them stronger, faster, better!þ
Korean: 당신은 그들을 더 강하고, 더 빠르고, 더 좋게 만들 수 있습니다!þ

English: I think they’re fine just the way they are, thanks.þ
Korean: 내 생각에는 그 사람들이 있는 그대로 괜찮은 것 같아요. 고마워요.þ

English: But with the right upgradesþ...
I heard you, I’m just not interested, mate.þ
Korean: 들었어, 난 그냥 관심이 없어, 친구.þ

English: Think of the possibilities!þ
Just leave nature alone, yeah?þ
Does the smell not bother you?þ
A little, but you’re not that bad, mate!þ
Korean: 조금, 하지만 그렇게 나쁘지는 않잖아, 친구!þ

English: I am speaking of your creatures.þ
Korean: 나는 당신의 피조물에 대해 말하고 있습니다.þ

English: Oh, maybe. Some of them have really sensitive noses!þ
Korean: 아, 어쩌면. 그들 중 일부는 정말 민감한 코를 가지고 있습니다!þ

English: Your tools are inferior to anything I can craft.þ
Korean: 당신의 도구는 내가 만들 수 있는 어떤 도구보다 열등합니다.þ

English: My tools are much cheaper though.þ
Yes they are.þ
But, they get the job done!þ
Yes they do. Slowly.þ
Why do I talk to you…þ
Korean: 내가 왜 너한테 말을 하는 거지...þ

English: Are you interested in stocking some of my inventions?
Korean: 내 발명품 중 일부를 구입하는 데 관심이 있습니까?

English: That sounds great!
But I need to run my shop!þ
Then this business proposal is now moot.
Korean: 그렇다면 이 사업 제안은 이제 논란의 여지가 있습니다.

English: Well, I have to send a lot back home…þ
I suppose someone back in South City is doing research for you?þ
Korean: South City에 있는 누군가가 당신을 위해 연구를 하고 있는 것 같은데요?þ

English: You could say that…þ
Then I hope you share what you have learnt soon.þ
Korean: 그렇다면 곧 여러분이 배운 내용을 공유하길 바랍니다.þ

English: If all your Dinks could buy infinite knowledge, would you part with them?þ
Korean: 여러분의 모든 Dink가 무한한 지식을 구입할 수 있다면 그들과 헤어지시겠습니까?þ

English: Hmph. Certainly not.þ
But you would know everything.þ
Korean: 하지만 당신은 모든 것을 알고 있을 것입니다.þ

English: If I need something done, I would simply pay someone.þ
Korean: 뭔가 해야 할 일이 있으면 누군가에게 돈을 지불하면 됩니다.þ

English: <IslandName> is amazing for research.þ
I wouldn’t call a place crawling with critters amazing.þ
Korean: 나는 동물들이 기어 다니는 곳을 훌륭하다고 부르지 않을 것입니다.þ

English: But you can play with the very laws of nature here!þ
Korean: 하지만 여기서는 바로 자연의 법칙을 가지고 놀 수 있습니다!þ

English: If there were any laws I would have started suing long ago.
Korean: 만약 법이 있었다면 오래 전부터 고소를 시작했을 겁니다.

English: I am developing a machine that can turn tin into gold
Korean: 주석을 금으로 바꾸는 기계를 개발 중이에요

English: If you need someone to fund your research, talk to me.
Korean: 연구 자금을 지원해 줄 사람이 필요하면 나에게 말하세요.

English: Now that you mention it, I do require a large sum of <Dinks>.
Large sum? Count me out.
Have you ever tried to make a new plant?þ
Korean: 새로운 식물을 만들어보려고 시도해 본 적이 있나요?þ

English: How would I do that?þ
Perhaps you could splice the seeds?þ
I could never do that!þ
I do not understand…þ
It would hurt the seeds!þ
I require your assistance.þ
Sure!
Please stop bothering me when I am trying to work.þ
Korean: 제가 일하려고 할 때 저를 괴롭히지 마세요.þ

English: I thought I was helping…þ
You were not.þ
What is your favourite plant?þ
Like, it’s hard to pick one type…þ
Type? I want to see the specific plant.þ
I, like, love them all equally.þ
Impossible.þ
Have you ever considered a different field?þ
Korean: 다른 분야를 생각해 본 적 있나요?þ

English: Further north, you mean?þ
I mean some other occupation.þ
Oh. All the time! But what about my customers?þ
Korean: 오. 항상! 하지만 내 고객은 어떻습니까?þ

English: I believe they would survive.þ
I spent yesterday arranging my instruments.þ
Is that why you cancelled your appointment?þ
I did not make an appointment.þ
I’m free tomorrow, my client list is pretty shortþ.
Korean: 내일 한가해요. 제 고객 목록이 꽤 짧거든요þ.

English: Of that, I am certain.þ
Have you considered adding restraints to your chair?þ
Korean: 의자에 고정 장치를 추가하는 것을 고려해 보셨나요?þ

English: I don’t think it’s going to go anywhereþ.
I was thinking of your customersþ.
Oh, might be an idea, then. Safety first!þ
Korean: 아, 그렇다면 좋은 생각이겠네요. 안전 제일!þ

English: How do you sterilise your equipment?þ
Sterra what?þ
I mean, how do you clean everything?þ
Korean: 내 말은, 모든 것을 어떻게 청소합니까?þ

English: Just good old fashioned elbow grease, darlþ
Korean: 그냥 좋은 구식 팔꿈치 그리스야, 달링þ

English: …I feel ill.þ
They are necessary for my work.þ
I just never see you wear them.þ
Korean: 나는 당신이 그것을 입는 것을 본 적이 없습니다.þ

English: You never see me at work.þ
Korean: 당신은 직장에서 나를 본 적이 없습니다.þ

English: You sure they’re just not for show?þ
Korean: 그냥 보여주기 위한 게 아닌 게 확실해요?þ

English: Do you know why the food has these effects?
Korean: 음식이 왜 이런 영향을 미치는지 아시나요?

English: What difference does that make?
To achieve a deeper understanding!
Would that make it taste better?

English: You've arrived on the island! Fletch has given you a Base Tent and has asked you to look around and find a spot where you would like to settle.þþFeel free to ask Fletch questions about the island. She can be found wandering around near the Dock.
Korean: 섬에 도착했어요! Fletch는 당신에게 베이스 텐트를 주며 주변을 둘러보고 정착하고 싶은 장소를 찾아보라고 요청했습니다.þþ섬에 관해 Fletch에게 질문을 해보세요. 그녀는 부두 근처를 돌아다니는 것을 볼 수 있습니다.

English: A Base of Operations

Fletch has given you your own Tent! This will be your home for the time being, so take your time deciding where to set it up. Fletch has suggested setting it up closeby to the Base Tent.þþþþOnce you’ve got your tent set up, speak to Fletch.þ
Korean: Fletch가 당신에게 당신만의 텐트를 주었습니다! 이곳은 당분간 귀하의 집이 될 것이므로 어디에 설치할 것인지 시간을 갖고 결정하십시오. Fletch는 베이스 텐트 가까이에 설치할 것을 제안했습니다.þþþþ텐트를 설치한 후 Fletch와 대화하세요.þ

English: Your new home!
<IslandName> needs 5 permanent residents before South City will recognise it as an official settlement.þþDoing favours and spending Dinks at Visitor's tents might encourage them to stay.
Korean: <IslandName>은 South City가 공식 정착지로 인정하기 전에 5명의 영주권자가 필요합니다.þþ방문객의 텐트에서 호의를 베풀고 딩크를 보내는 것은 그들이 머물도록 장려할 수 있습니다.

English: Five's a Town

Fletch has asked you to find a place for the Visiting Site Deed. Once this deed has been placed, your camp will be ready to accommodate visitors from all over the place!þþReturn to Fletch once the deed has been placed.
Korean: Fletch는 방문 사이트 증서를 위한 장소를 찾아달라고 요청했습니다. 이 증서가 작성되면 캠프는 전 세계에서 오는 방문객을 수용할 준비가 된 것입니다!þþ증서가 작성되면 Fletch로 돌아가세요.

English: A place for Visitors
Franklyn has asked me to find more Berkonium ore and deliver it to him.
Korean: 프랭클린은 나에게 베르코늄 광석을 더 찾아 자신에게 전해 달라고 부탁했습니다.

English: A Rare Ore
Fletch has asked you to find some fruit and cook it on the fire.
Korean: 플레치는 과일을 찾아 불에 구워달라고 부탁했습니다.

English: Bush Tucker

Fletch hasn't got anything else for you today! You should take some time to look around the island a bit, pick some fruit and maybe catch some bugs.þþRest in your sleeping bag once you're all done, and you will sleep until tomorrow.
Korean: Fletch는 오늘 당신을 위한 다른 어떤 것도 갖고 있지 않습니다! 섬을 조금 둘러보고, 과일을 따고, 벌레도 잡을 수 있는 시간을 가져야 합니다.þþ모든 일을 마친 후 침낭에서 쉬고 내일까지 잠을 잘 수 있습니다.

English: R n' R
Fletch has asked you to buy a tablesaw from John. She's given you half the Dinks you will need, but you'll have to earn some for youself. þþTry selling  items to John to earn some more Dinks.
Korean: Fletch는 John에게서 테이블톱을 구입해 달라고 요청했습니다. 그녀는 당신에게 필요한 Dink의 절반을 주지만, 일부는 스스로 벌어야 합니다. þþ더 많은 Dink를 얻으려면 John에게 아이템을 판매해 보세요.

English: Dinks and Tablesaws
Fletch has asked you to find a list of items (You will have to craft a campfire yourself)þOnce you have collected the items Fletch will teach you how to make Tin Ore Bars.
Korean: Fletch가 아이템 목록을 찾아달라고 요청했습니다. (캠프파이어는 직접 제작해야 합니다.)þ아이템을 수집하면 Fletch가 주석 광석 주괴 만드는 법을 가르쳐줄 것입니다.

English: Building Materials
Craft a crude furnace, place 5 Tin Ore inside and wait.
Korean: 조악한 용광로를 제작하고 그 안에 주석 광석 5개를 넣고 기다리세요.

English: Smelting Ore
Fletch thinks that by doing favours for visitors and spending money at their stores, they might be convinced to stay permanently.
Korean: Fletch는 방문객들에게 호의를 베풀고 매장에서 돈을 지출함으로써 그들이 영구적으로 머물도록 확신할 수 있다고 생각합니다.

English: Convince John to Stay
Request for <npcName>
something you've made me at a cooking table
Korean: 당신이 요리 테이블에서 나에게 만든 것

English: something to eat
Spend Dinks or sell items in John's tent
Korean: 존의 텐트에서 Dink를 사용하거나 아이템을 판매하세요

English: taken in <biomeName>
taken near this location

<itemName> Requirements
Crafting <itemName>

Did you know, all the seeds I sell are from my own collection?þ
French: Savais-tu que toutes les graines que je vends proviennent de ma propre collection ?
Russian: А ты знаешь, что все семена я продаю из моей собственной коллекции?
Chinese (Simplified): 我出售的种子全是自己收集来的，你知道吗？
Japanese: ウチで売っている種は全部、私自身のコレクションからってことは知ってた？
Korean: 그거 알아? 내가 파는 씨앗들은 전부 개인 컬렉션에 있던 물건들이야.
Indonesian: Tahukah kamu, semua bibit yang kujual berasal dari koleksiku sendiri?
Spanish (Latin Americas): ¿Sabías que todas las semillas que vendo son de mi colección?
Portuguese: Você sabia que todas as sementes que vendo são da minha própria coleção?
German: Wusstest du, dass alle Samen, die ich verkaufe, aus meiner eigenen Sammlung stammen?

English: <shy>I started collecting the seeds when I was, like, just a little girl.þ
French: <shy>J'ai commencé à collectionner des graines quand j'étais, genre, une petite fille.
Russian: <shy>Я начала собирать семена, когда была еще как бы маленькой девочкой.
Japanese: <shy>幼い子供の頃から、種を集めているよ。
Indonesian: <shy>Aku mulai mengumpulkan bibit ketika aku masih seorang gadis kecil.
Spanish (Latin Americas): <shy>Comencé a coleccionar semillas cuando era pequeña.
Portuguese: <shy>Eu comecei a colecionar as sementes quando eu era apenas, tipo, uma garotinha.
German: <shy>Ich habe mit dem Sammeln von Saatgut angefangen, als ich echt noch ein kleines Mädchen war.

English: I would spend all the <Dinks> I had saved up and buy them wherever I could.þ
French: Je dépensais tous les <Dinks> que j'avais économisés et je les achetais dès que je le pouvais.
Russian: Я могла бы потратить все <Dinks>, которые накопила, и покупать их, где бы только нашла.
Chinese (Simplified): 我把存下里的<Dinks>全部拿去买种子了。
Japanese: 買える場合はいつでも、貯めた<Dinks>を全部使って集めてきた。
Korean: 기회가 있을 때마다 아껴 뒀던 <Dinks>를 전부 써서 씨앗을 구입했지.
Indonesian: Aku akan menghabiskan semua <Dinks> yang aku tabung dan membelinya di mana pun aku bisa.
Spanish (Latin Americas): Gastaba todos los <Dinks> que había ahorrado para comprarlas.
Portuguese: Eu gastava todos os <Dinks> que eu economizei e as comprava sempre que podia.
German: Ich habe alle <Dinks>, die ich gespart hatte, dafür ausgegeben und Samen gekauft, wann immer ich konnte.

English: I didn’t have a lot of space on my family’s <AirShip>. So I could only grow certain plants at certain times.þ
French: Je n'avais pas beaucoup de place sur le <AirShip> de ma famille. Donc je ne pouvais faire pousser que certaines plantes à la fois.
Russian: <AirShip> моей семьи не был особо просторным, так что я могла выращивать только некоторые растения в определенное время.
Chinese (Simplified): 我家的<AirShip>空间不大，所以只能在特定时间种植特定植物。
Japanese: 家族の<AirShip>にはそんなにスペースがなかったから、限られた時期に一部の植物を育てることしかできなかった。
Korean: 우리 가족의 <AirShip>에는 공간이 부족해서 특정 시간에 특정한 식물만 키울 수 있었어.
Indonesian: Waktu itu aku tidak punya banyak lahan di <AirShip> keluargaku. Jadi aku hanya bisa menanam tanaman tertentu pada waktu-waktu tertentu.
Spanish (Latin Americas): No tenía mucho espacio en el <AirShip> de mi familia, así que solo cultivaba ciertas plantas en ciertos momentos.
Portuguese: Eu não tinha muito espaço na <AirShip> da minha família. Então eu só conseguia cultivar determinadas plantas em determinadas épocas.
German: Im <AirShip> meiner Familie hatte ich nicht viel Platz. Darum konnte ich immer nur bestimmte Pflanzen zu bestimmten Zeiten anbauen.

English: I’ve always wanted some space to spread out, you know. Have a whole garden!þ
French: J'ai toujours voulu de l'espace pour prendre mes aises, tu sais. Un vrai jardin !
Russian: Мне всегда хотелось больше места, чтобы развернуться, понимаешь. Иметь в распоряжении целый сад!
Chinese (Simplified): 我一直梦想拥有一块地方搭建整座花园！
Japanese: ずっと、広々とした空間を求めていた。庭園を持つという夢だね！
Korean: 항상 커다란 정원을 가지는 게 꿈이었어!
Indonesian: Aku selalu ingin punya lahan yang luas. Punya kebun yang luas!
Spanish (Latin Americas): Siempre quise más espacio para tener un jardín completo.
Portuguese: Eu sempre quis um espaço para espalhá-las, sabe? Ter um jardim completo!
German: Ich wollte schon immer etwas Platz haben, um mich auszubreiten, weißt du? Einen ganzen Garten!

English: <haha>Even though I spent so much time in the air, I guess I, like, always wanted to be down here in the dirt and stuff.þ
French: <haha>Même si j'ai passé tant de temps dans les airs, je pense que, genre, j'ai toujours voulu être ici bas dans la poussière et tout.
Russian: <haha>Несмотря на то, что я провела так много времени в воздухе, мне как бы всегда хотелось быть здесь, копаться в земле и все такое.
Chinese (Simplified): <haha>虽然我大部分时间在天上，但却一直想和大地接触。
Japanese: <haha>空で長い時間を過ごしたけど、こんな土などがある場所に身を置きたいと思っていた。
Korean: <haha>하늘에서 많은 시간을 보내긴 했지만 항상 땅에서 흙을 만지고 싶었어.
Indonesian: <haha>Meskipun aku menghabiskan begitu banyak waktu di atas udara, aku merasa seperti selalu ingin berada di sini, di atas tanah.
Spanish (Latin Americas): <haha>A pesar de que pasé tanto tiempo de mi vida en el aire, siempre quise estar aquí en la tierra.
Portuguese: <haha>Apesar de eu ter passado tanto tempo no ar, acho que eu, tipo, sempre quis estar aqui embaixo na terra e tal.
German: <haha>Auch wenn ich vielleicht zu viel Zeit auf den Wolken verbringe, wollte ich echt schon immer hier unten im Dreck wühlen und so.

English: That’s why I had to leave my family and stuff.þ
French: C'est pour cela que j'ai dû quitter ma famille et tout.
Russian: Вот почему я должна была покинуть семью и прочее.
Japanese: だから家族達と別れたんだよ。
Indonesian: Itulah mengapa aku harus meninggalkan keluargaku dan sebagainya.
Spanish (Latin Americas): Por eso tuve que dejar a mi familia.
Portuguese: É por isso que eu tive de deixar minha família e tal.
German: Darum musste ich meine Familie verlassen und so.

English: <sigh>Although, I miss them a lot, you know <PlayerName>.þ
French: <sigh>Même s'ils me manquent beaucoup, tu sais <PlayerName>.
Russian: <sigh>Хотя знаешь, <PlayerName>, я очень по ним скучаю.
Japanese: <sigh><PlayerName>も分かってくれると思うけど、すごく恋しくは思っている。
Indonesian: <sigh>Meskipun, jujur, aku sangat merindukan mereka, <PlayerName>.
Portuguese: <sigh>Mas eu sinto muita falta deles, sabe, <PlayerName>?
German: <sigh>Auch wenn ich sie sehr vermisse, weißt du, <PlayerName>?

English: <sigh>Hey <PlayerName>...
French: <sigh>Hé <PlayerName>...
Russian: <sigh>Привет, <PlayerName>...
Indonesian: <sigh>Hei <PlayerName>...
German: <sigh>Hi, <PlayerName> …

English: I’ve been kinda like, thinking about my family and stuff.
French: Je pense beaucoup, genre, à ma famille et tout.
Russian: Я как бы думала о своей семье и всем таком.
Chinese (Simplified): 我最近常常想起家里人。
Japanese: 家族達のことを考えたりしていた。
Indonesian: Aku sedang memikirkan tentang keluargaku dan hal-hal lainnya.
Spanish (Latin Americas): Estuve pensando en mi familia y eso.
Portuguese: Eu estive, tipo, pensando na minha família e tal.
German: Ich habe irgendwie über meine Familie und so nachgedacht.

English: I didn’t leave them on the best of terms…þ
French: On ne s'est pas quittés en très bons termes…
Russian: Я с ними рассталась не в самых лучших отношениях...
Chinese (Simplified): 我离开的时候并不愉快…
Japanese: あまり円満なお別れではなかったんだ…
Korean: 가족을 떠날 때 분위기가 별로 좋지 않았어…
Indonesian: Aku pergi dari keluargaku tidak dengan cara yang baik-baik...
Portuguese: Eu não fui embora numa boa...
German: Ich habe sie nicht gerade in schönster Harmonie verlassen …

English: I guess you could say I kinda, like, ran away from them..þ
French: Je suppose qu'on peut dire que, genre, je me suis enfuie loin d'eux.
Russian: Думаю, ты сейчас скажешь, что я как бы сбежала от них...
Chinese (Simplified): 可以算得上是离家出走…
Japanese: 逃げ出した、と言っても間違いではないぐらいに…
Korean: 가족으로부터 도망쳐 나왔다고 할 수도 있겠지.
Indonesian: Bisa dibilang aku lebih seperti kabur dari mereka...
Spanish (Latin Americas): Se podría decir que hui de casa.
Portuguese: Acho que você poderia dizer que eu, tipo, fugi deles...
German: Man könnte wohl sagen, ich bin irgendwie von zu Hause abgehauen …

English: <boohoo>I didn’t even leave a note or anything. I just jumped out of the <AirShip> one night.þþ
French: <boohoo>Je n'ai même pas laissé un mot, ni rien. J'ai juste sauté du <AirShip> une nuit.
Russian: <boohoo>Я даже не оставила записку или что-то еще — просто в одну ночь выпрыгнула из <AirShip>.
Chinese (Simplified): <boohoo>一天夜里，我直接跳出了<AirShip>，连一张便条都没留下。
Japanese: <boohoo>置き手紙もせずに、ある夜に<AirShip>から抜け出した。
Korean: <boohoo>편지조차 남기지 않았고 그냥 어느 날 밤 <AirShip>에서 뛰어 내렸어.
Indonesian: <boohoo>Aku bahkan tidak meninggalkan pesan atau apapun. Aku hanya langsung melompat keluar dari <AirShip> pada suatu malam.
Spanish (Latin Americas): <boohoo>Ni siquiera dejé una nota. Solo salté del <AirShip> una noche.
Portuguese: <boohoo>Eu nem deixei um recado nem nada. Eu apenas pulei da <AirShip> numa noite.
German: <boohoo>Ich habe nicht einmal einen Zettel oder so hinterlassen. Ich bin einfach in irgendeiner Nacht aus dem <AirShip> gesprungen.

English: They didn’t understand that I wanted to stay in one place. þ
French: Ils ne comprenaient pas que je voulais rester dans un même endroit.
Russian: Они не понимали, что я хочу оставаться на одном месте.
Chinese (Simplified): 他们不理解为什么我想待在一个地方。
Japanese: どこか1ヶ所に落ち着きたいという考えを理解してもらえなかったんだ。
Korean: 내가 한곳에 머물고 싶어하는 걸 이해하지 못했어.
Indonesian: Mereka tidak mengerti bahwa aku hanya ingin tinggal di satu tempat.
Spanish (Latin Americas): Ellos no entendían que yo quería establecerme en un lugar.
Portuguese: Eles não entendiam que eu queria ficar num só lugar.
German: Sie haben nicht verstanden, dass ich an einem Ort bleiben wollte.

English: I just wanted to get to know some people, you know, make friends with someone and stuff.þ
French: Je voulais juste apprendre à connaître des gens, tu sais, me faire des amis et tout.
Russian: Я просто хотела познакомиться с людьми, знаешь, подружиться с кем-нибудь и все такое.
Chinese (Simplified): 我只是想多认识些人，和他们做朋友。
Japanese: 人のことを知ったり、友達を作ったりしたいとばかり願っていた。
Korean: 난 그냥 사람들을 알아가며 친구들을 사귀고 싶었어.
Indonesian: Aku hanya ingin mengenal beberapa orang, lho, berteman dengan seseorang dan semacamnya.
Spanish (Latin Americas): Quería conocer gente, hacer amigos y eso.
Portuguese: Eu só queria conhecer algumas pessoas, sabe? Fazer amizade com alguém e tal.
German: Ich wollte einfach ein paar Leute kennenlernen, weißt du? Mich mit jemandem anfreunden und so.

English: <pumped> I do miss them, <PlayerName>. þ
French: <pumped> Ils me manquent, <PlayerName>.
Russian: <pumped> Я действительно по ним скучаю, <PlayerName>.
Japanese: <pumped>ねえ、<PlayerName>。家族にはまた会いたいと思っている、。
Indonesian: <pumped> Aku merindukan mereka, <PlayerName>.
German: <pumped> Ich vermisse sie sehr, <PlayerName>.

English: But to be honest with you, coming to <IslandName> is, like, the most bonza thing that has ever happened to me.þ
French: Mais pour être honnête avec toi, venir sur <IslandName> est, genre, la chose la plus folle qui me soit jamais arrivée.
Russian: Но если быть с тобой честной, приехать на остров <IslandName> как бы было самым крутым, что со мной когда-либо произошло.
Chinese (Simplified): 说实话，能到<IslandName>来是我三生有幸。
Japanese: でも正直に言うと、<IslandName>に来たことは、人生最高の出来事なんだ。
Korean: 하지만 솔직히 <IslandName>에 온 건 내 인생 최고의 사건이었어.
Indonesian: Tetapi sejujurnya, datang ke <IslandName> adalah hal yang paling luar biasa yang pernah terjadi padaku.
Spanish (Latin Americas): Aunque, para ser sincera, venir a <IslandName> es una de las mejores cosas que me ha ocurrido.
Portuguese: Mas, para ser honesta com você, chegar até a <IslandName> é, tipo, a coisa mais espetacular que já aconteceu comigo.
German: Aber um ehrlich zu sein, dass ich nach <IslandName> gekommen bin, ist echt das Tollste, was mir je passiert ist.

English: I’ve gotten close to everyone here on the <IslandName>.þ
French: Je suis devenue proche avec tout le monde ici sur <IslandName>.
Russian: Я сблизилась со всеми здесь на острове <IslandName>.
Chinese (Simplified): 我和<IslandName>的每个人都相处得很亲密。
Indonesian: Aku menjadi dekat dengan semua orang di <IslandName> ini.
Spanish (Latin Americas): Ahora he entablado relación con todos aquí en <IslandName>.
Portuguese: Eu me aproximei de todos aqui em <IslandName>.
German: Mir sind alle hier auf <IslandName> echt ans Herz gewachsen.

English: Especially you, <PlayerName>.þ
French: Surtout toi, <PlayerName>.
Russian: Особенно с тобой, <PlayerName>.
Indonesian: Terutama kamu, <PlayerName>.
German: Besonders du, <PlayerName>.

English: <haha>So, like, thanks for being my friend. My first friend!þ
French: <haha>Donc, genre, merci d'être mon ami. Mon premier ami !
Russian: <haha>Так что как бы спасибо, что ты мой друг. Мой первый друг!
Chinese (Simplified): <haha>谢谢你成为我的朋友，成为我第一个朋友！
Japanese: <haha>私の友人になってくれてありがとう。最初の友達だよ！
Korean: <haha>친구가 되어줘서 고마워, 나의 첫 번째 친구!
Indonesian: <haha>Jadi, terima kasih telah menjadi temanku. Teman pertamaku!
Spanish (Latin Americas): <haha>Gracias por tu amistad. De hecho, ¡la primera que hice!
Portuguese: <haha>Então, tipo, agradeço por sua amizade. A primeira!
German: <haha>Darum, echt, danke, dass du mein Freund bist. Mein erster Freund!

English: þ<PlayerName>, I just wanted to thank you.þþ
French: <PlayerName>, je voulais juste te remercier.
Russian: <PlayerName>, я просто хотела тебя поблагодарить.
Japanese: とにかく、<PlayerName>に感謝を伝えたい。
Indonesian: <PlayerName>, aku hanya ingin mengucapkan terima kasih.
German: <PlayerName>, ich wollte dir einfach mal danke sagen.

English: <no>Before I came to <IslandName> I’ve felt like I’ve never had a home.þþþ
French: <no>Avant de venir sur <IslandName> j'avais l'impression de n'avoir jamais eu de maison.
Russian: <no>Прежде чем я приехала на остров <IslandName>, я чувствовала, будто у меня никогда не было дома.
Chinese (Simplified): <no>来到<IslandName>之前，我一直缺少家的感觉。
Japanese: <no><IslandName>に来る前は、我が家があると感じたことがなかった。
Korean: <no><IslandName>에 오기 전에는 집이 있다는 느낌을 받아본 적이 없었어.
Indonesian: <no>Sebelum aku datang ke <IslandName>, aku merasa tidak pernah punya rumah.
Spanish (Latin Americas): <no>Antes de venir a <IslandName>, sentía que nunca había tenido un hogar.
Portuguese: <no>Antes de eu vir para a <IslandName>, sentia que nunca teria um lar.
German: <no>Bevor ich nach <IslandName> kam, habe ich mich nirgendwo zu Hause gefühlt.

English: <shy>I’ve never been able to, like, put down roots, so to say.þ
French: <shy>Je n'ai jamais pu, genre, poser mes valises quelque part, en quelque sorte.
Russian: <shy>Мне ни разу не удалось, так сказать, пустить корни.
Chinese (Simplified): <shy>我从未有机会在一个地方扎根。
Japanese: <shy>いわゆる、根を下ろすということができなかったんだ。
Korean: <shy>한 번도 제대로 정착이란 걸 해본 적이 없었거든.
Indonesian: <shy>Aku tidak pernah bisa, istilahnya, menjadi terikat di satu tempat.
Spanish (Latin Americas): <shy>Nunca pude echar raíces, por así decirlo.
Portuguese: <shy>Eu nunca consegui, tipo, criar raízes, digamos assim.
German: <shy>Echt, ich konnte sozusagen niemals Wurzeln schlagen.

English: <yes>But thanks to you and everyone else here, <IslandName>, like, really feels like my home now.þ
French: <yes>Mais grâce à toi et à toutes les autres personnes ici, je me sens, genre, vraiment chez moi maintenant sur <IslandName>.
Russian: <yes>Но благодаря тебе и всем остальным, теперь остров <IslandName>, как бы, я действительно ощущаю как свой дом.
Chinese (Simplified): <yes>感谢你和<IslandName>的其他人，我现在找到了家的感觉。
Japanese: <yes>でも、<IslandName>やみんなのおかげで、ここが我が家だと確実に感じている。
Korean: <yes>하지만 너를 비롯한 다른 모든 주민들 덕분에 이제 <IslandName>은 나의 진정한 집처럼 느껴져.
Indonesian: <yes>Tetapi berkat kamu dan semua orang di sini, <IslandName>, sekarang benar-benar terasa seperti rumahku.
Spanish (Latin Americas): <yes>Pero gracias a ti y a todos en <IslandName>, ahora siento que este es mi hogar.
Portuguese: <yes>Mas, graças a você e a todos aqui, a <IslandName>, tipo, realmente parece ser meu lar agora.
German: <yes>Aber dank dir und allen anderen hier fühle ich mich jetzt auf <IslandName> echt zu Hause.

English: <thinking>It snuck up on me so slowly that I guess I didn’t notice it and stuff.þ
French: <thinking>C'est venu petit à petit donc je pense que je ne m'en suis pas rendu compte.
Russian: <thinking>Это подкралось ко мне так медленно, что, думаю, я даже не заметила.
Chinese (Simplified): <thinking>这种感觉悄悄地在我内心生根发芽，我甚至都没注意到。
Japanese: <thinking>その道のりはゆっくりだったから、気づかなかったようだね。
Korean: <thinking>조금씩 스며든 생각이라 그런지 처음에는 몰랐던 것 같아.
Indonesian: <thinking>Hal ini terjadi secara perlahan-lahan sehingga aku tidak menyadarinya.
Spanish (Latin Americas): <thinking>Ocurrió de a poco y sigilosamente, así que no me di cuenta.
Portuguese: <thinking>Me pegou tão desprevenida que eu acho que não tinha percebido e tal.
German: <thinking>Ihr habt euch so langsam in mein Herz geschlichen, dass ich es wohl gar nicht bemerkt habe und so.

English: <shy>So, yeah, like, thanks, <PlayerName>.þ
French: <shy>Donc, ouais, genre, merci, <PlayerName>.
Russian: <shy>Так что да, как бы, спасибо, <PlayerName>.
Japanese: <shy>だからあらためて言わせておくれ。<PlayerName>、ありがとう。
Indonesian: <shy>Jadi, ya, terima kasih, <PlayerName>.
German: <shy>Also ja, echt, danke, <PlayerName>.

English: <glee>I’m so happy to be here on <IslandName>!
French: <glee>Je suis tellement heureuse d'être ici sur <IslandName> !
Russian: <glee>Я так рада быть здесь на острове <IslandName>!
Japanese: <glee><IslandName>にいることができて嬉しいよ！
Indonesian: <glee>Aku sangat senang berada di <IslandName>!
Portuguese: <glee>Estou tão feliz de estar aqui em <IslandName>!
German: <glee>Ich bin so froh, dass ich hier auf <IslandName> bin!

English: <thinking>I have read of phenomena such as this happening… þ
French: <thinking>J'ai lu quelque chose à propos de tels phénomènes…
Russian: <thinking>Я читала, что бывают такие феномены…
Japanese: <thinking>こんな現象が起きていると聞いたことがある…
Indonesian: <thinking>Aku pernah membaca fenomena seperti ini terjadi...
Spanish (Latin Americas): <thinking>He leído sobre fenómenos similares que ocurrieron.
Portuguese: <thinking>Eu li sobre um fenômeno como esse acontecendo...
German: <thinking>Ich habe von derartigen Phänomenen gelesen …

English: Oh. Hello <PlayerName>.þ
French: Oh. Bonjour <PlayerName>.
Russian: О, привет, <PlayerName>.
Indonesian: Oh, halo <PlayerName>.
German: Oh, hallo, <PlayerName>.

English: <no>Very well...
French: <no>Très bien...
Russian: <no>Очень хорошо...
Indonesian: <no>Baiklah...
German: <no>In Ordnung …

English: <yes>These meteors are caused by streams of cosmic debris entering the atmosphere.
French: <yes>Ces météorites sont provoquées par des flux de débris cosmiques qui pénètrent dans l'atmosphère.
Russian: <yes>Эти метеоры вызываются потоками космичесикх обломков, входящих в атмосферу.
Japanese: <yes>これらの流星は、大気圏に突入した宇宙ゴミの流れによって発生するの。
Korean: <yes>유성이 생기는 이유는 우주의 잔해가 대기권으로 흘러들어오기 때문이야.
Indonesian: <yes>Meteor-meteor ini disebabkan oleh aliran puing-puing kosmik yang memasuki atmosfer.
Spanish (Latin Americas): <yes>Los meteoritos se producen por ráfagas de restos cósmicos que entran en la atmósfera.
Portuguese: <yes>Esses meteoros são causados por rastros de destroços cósmicos que entram na atmosfera.
German: <yes>Diese Meteore werden durch Ströme von kosmischem Geröll verursacht, das in die Atmosphäre eindringt.

English: <glee>It is truly fascinating.
French: <glee>C'est vraiment fascinant.
Russian: <glee>Действительно захватывает.
Indonesian: <glee>Sungguh menarik.
German: <glee>Das ist echt faszinierend.

English: I have research to conduct.
French: J'ai des recherches à faire.
Russian: Мне нужно провести исследование.
Japanese: 調べていることがあるの。
Indonesian: Aku harus melakukan penelitian.
German: Ich muss Nachforschungen anstellen.

English: Meteor showers can be predicted as planet passes through the same streams of cosmic debris at roughly the same time each year
French: Les pluies de météorites sont prévisibles car la planète traverse les mêmes flux de débris cosmiques à peu près au même moment chaque année
Russian: Метеоритные дожди можно прогнозировать, так как планета проходит через те же потоки космических обломков примерно в одно и то же время каждый год
Japanese: 流星群は、惑星が毎年ほぼ同時期に同じ宇宙ゴミの流れを通過するから、予測することが可能よ。
Korean: 유성우를 예측할 수 있는 이유는 매년 대략 같은 시기에 행성이 우주 잔해의 흐름을 통과하기 때문이야.
Indonesian: Hujan meteor bisa diprediksi saat planet melewati aliran puing-puing kosmik yang sama pada waktu yang kurang lebih sama setiap tahunnya.
Spanish (Latin Americas): Las lluvias de meteoritos pueden predecirse, ya que el planeta pasa por las mismas ráfagas de restos cósmicos al mismo tiempo cada año.
Portuguese: Chuvas de meteoros podem ser previstas como planetas passando pelos mesmos rastros de destroços cósmicos por volta da mesma época todo ano
German: Meteorschauer können vorhergesagt werden, da der Planet jedes Jahr etwa zur gleichen Zeit dieselben Ströme von kosmischem Geröll passiert.

English: That's how my <itemName> can forecast when and where these showers can be observed.
French: C'est ainsi que ma <itemName> peut prévoir quand et où ces pluies peuvent être observées.
Russian: Таким образом, используя <itemName>, мы можем прогнозировать, где и когда будут наблюдаться такие дожди.
Japanese: そうやって私の<itemName>は、いつ、どこで流星群がみられるかを予測している　の。
Korean: 그래서 내 <itemName>은 언제 어디서 유성우를 관찰할 수 있는지 예측할 수 있어.
Indonesian: Begitulah cara <itemName> milikku bisa memperkirakan kapan dan di mana hujan meteor ini bisa diamati.
Spanish (Latin Americas): Así es como mi <itemName> puede predecir cuándo y dónde se verán estas lluvias.
Portuguese: É assim que meu <itemName> pode prever quando e de onde essas chuvas podem ser observadas.
German: Darum kann mein <itemName> vorhersagen, wann und wo diese Schauer beobachtet werden können.

English: Oh, those are my special and super rare keys.
French: Oh, ce sont mes clés spéciales et très rares.
Chinese (Simplified): 这些是超级特别和罕见的钥匙。
Japanese: それは特別で、非常に貴重な鍵だ。
Korean: 아, 그건 내 특별하고 매우 희귀한 열쇠야.
Portuguese: Ah, essas são minhas chaves especiais e super-raras.
German: Oh, das sind meine besonderen und sehr seltenen Schlüssel.

English: You won't find a better price for these puppies.
French: Tu ne trouveras pas meilleur prix pour ces beautés.
Chinese (Simplified): 价格已经是最实惠的了。
Japanese: これ以上お得な価格では手に入れられないよ。
Korean: 이 강아지에 대해 더 나은 가격을 찾을 수 없습니다.
Portuguese: Você não encontrará um preço melhor por essas belezinhas.
German: Du findest nirgends einen besseren Preis für diese Schätzchen.

English: I'm practically giving them away at <buyItemPrice> for a pack of 5.
French: Je les donne presque gratuitement à <buyItemPrice> pour un lot de 5.
Chinese (Simplified): <buyItemPrice>，每包 5 个，简直是免费赠送。
Japanese: 5点セットで<buyItemPrice>だ。実質無料だよ。
Portuguese: Estou praticamente dando-as de graça por <buyItemPrice> por um pacote com cinco.
German: Ich verschenke sie quasi im Fünferpack für <buyItemPrice>.

English: I'll take it!
French: Je prends !
German: Nehme ich!

English: No thanks.
French: Non, merci.
German: Nein, danke.

English: Good choice, <PlayerName>.
French: Excellent choix, <PlayerName>.
German: Gute Wahl, <PlayerName>.

English: <no>Like I said, you won't find them at a better price.
French: <no>Comme je l'ai dit, tu ne les trouveras pas à meilleur prix.
Chinese (Simplified): <no>如我所说，这已经是最好的价格。
Japanese: <no>さっきも言ったけど、これ以上お得な価格はないよ。
Korean: <no>내가 말했듯이, 이보다 더 좋은 가격에는 찾을 수 없습니다.
Portuguese: <no>Como eu disse, você não as encontrará por um preço melhor.
German: <no>Wie gesagt, du findest sie nirgends zu einem besseren Preis.

English: Hmmm...
French: Hum...
German: Hmmm …

English: I'll see you when you change your mind.
French: Je te verrai quand tu auras changé d'avis.
Chinese (Simplified): 你要是改变主意，记得来找我。
Japanese: 気が変わったら、また来てくれ。
Portuguese: Vejo você depois quando mudar de ideia.
German: Wir sehen uns, wenn du es dir anders überlegst.

English: <no>Like I said, you won't find them at a better price.
French: <no>Comme je l'ai dit, tu ne les trouveras pas à meilleur prix.
Chinese (Simplified): <no>如我所说，这已经是最好的价格。
Japanese: <no>さっきも言ったけど、これ以上お得な価格はないよ。
Korean: <no>내가 말했듯이, 이보다 더 좋은 가격에는 찾을 수 없습니다.
Portuguese: <no>Como eu disse, você não as encontrará por um preço melhor.
German: <no>Wie gesagt, du findest sie nirgends zu einem besseren Preis.

English: <thinking>Let's see...
French: <thinking>Voyons...
German: <thinking>Mal sehen ...

English: All up, I can offer you <$>?
French: Tout inclus, je peux te proposer <$> ?
Korean: 모든 것을 제안해 드릴 수 있습니다. <$>?
Portuguese: Tudo bem. Posso oferecer <$> para você?
German: Alles in allem kann ich dir <$> bieten?

English: Sounds good!
French: Cela me semble bien !
German: Klingt gut!

English: No thanks.
French: Non, merci.
German: Nein, danke.

English: Very good! I'll take these items and here is your <$>.
French: Très bien ! Je prends ces objets et voici tes <$>.
Japanese: 素晴らしい！ではアイテムをいただき、<$>は君のものだ。
Korean: 매우 좋은! 제가 이 물건들을 가져갈 테니 여기 <$>를 가져가세요.
Portuguese: Muito bem! Vou pegar esses itens e aqui está seu <$>.

English: Oh and I believe I owe you <ticketAmount>.þ
French: Oh et je crois que je te dois <ticketAmount>.
Japanese: ああ、<ticketAmount>の借りがあるよね。
Korean: 아 그리고 <ticketAmount> 빚이 있는 것 같아요.þ
Portuguese: Ah, e acredito que devo <ticketAmount> para você.

English: You’ll get one <itemName> for each fish you sell me.þ
French: Tu recevras un(e) <itemName> pour chaque poisson que tu me vends.
Japanese: 魚1匹につき、<itemName>を支払おう。
Korean: 당신이 나에게 판매한 각 생선에 대해 하나의 <itemName>을(를) 받게 됩니다.þ
Portuguese: Você terá um <itemName> para cada peixe que me vender.

English: Don’t forget to check out the green prize box to see what your <itemName> can get you.
French: N'oublie pas de consulter la boîte à prix verte pour voir ce que <itemName> peut te rapporter.
Japanese: 緑の賞品ボックスで、<itemName>で入手できるものを必ず確認してくれよ。
Korean: <itemName>이(가) 무엇을 얻을 수 있는지 보려면 녹색 상품 상자를 확인하는 것을 잊지 마세요.
Portuguese: Não se esqueça de conferir a grande caixa de prêmios para ver o que seu <itemName> consegue para você.

English: That's fine, mate.
French: Pas de souci, mon pote.

English: I'll just give you your stuff back.
French: Je vais juste te rendre tes affaires.

English: Thank you for visiting John's Goods! <yes>
French: Merci d'être venu à la Boutique de John ! <yes>
Japanese: ジョンズ・グッズへの来店ありがとう！<yes>
Portuguese: Agradeço a visita à loja Produtos do John! <yes>

English: All right... Lets see...
French: Très bien... Voyons voir...

English: It seems these items aren't worth anything, but I can still take them off your hands if you don't want them?
French: On dirait que ces objets ne valent pas grand-chose, mais je peux quand même t'en débarrasser si tu ne les veux pas ?
Chinese (Simplified): 这些物品一文不值，但如果你不想要了，不如给我？
Japanese: このアイテムには価値がないようだけど、いらないようなら受け取ることはできるよ。
Korean: 이 물건들은 아무 가치도 없는 것 같지만, 원치 않으시면 제가 당신 손에서 떼어드릴 수도 있나요?
Portuguese: Parece que esses itens não valem nada, mas ainda posso ficar com eles se você não quiser?

English: All right... Lets see...
French: Très bien... Voyons voir...

English: It seems these items aren't worth anything, but I can still take them off your hands if you don't want them?
French: On dirait que ces objets ne valent pas grand-chose, mais je peux quand même t'en débarrasser si tu ne les veux pas ?
Japanese: このアイテムには価値がないようだけど、いらないようなら受け取ることはできるよ。
Korean: 이 물건들은 아무 가치도 없는 것 같지만, 원치 않으시면 제가 당신 손에서 떼어드릴 수도 있나요?
Portuguese: Parece que esses itens não valem nada, mas ainda posso ficar com eles se você não quiser?

English: Alright, I'll take these off your hands.
French: Très bien, je vais t'en débarrasser.
Japanese: わかった。アイテムを受け取るよ。
Korean: 좋아, 이 물건을 네 손에서 떼어줄게.
Portuguese: Tudo bem. Vou tirar isso da sua mão.

English: Thank you for visiting John's Goods!
French: Merci d'être venu à la Boutique de John !
Japanese: ジョンズ・グッズへの来店ありがとう！
Portuguese: Agradeço a visita à loja Produtos do John!

French: <shy>Pas de souci !

French: Point de collecte d'animaux. Place l'animal dedans pour recevoir une récompense.
Japanese: 動物回収ポイント。中に動物を入れると、報酬を獲得できる。
Korean: 동물 수집 지점. 보상을 받으려면 동물을 안에 넣으세요.
Portuguese: Ponto de coleta de animais. Coloque o animal dentro para receber o prêmio.

English: The latest score added to the <compBook> before 5:00pm will be your final score.
French: Le score le plus récent ajouté dans le <compBook> avant 17 h sera ton score final.
Japanese: 午後5時までに<compBook>に記録した最新のスコアが最終スコアになる。
Korean: 오후 5시 이전에 <compBook>에 추가된 최신 점수가 최종 점수가 됩니다.
Portuguese: A pontuação mais recente adicionada ao <compBook> antes das 17:00 será sua pontuação final.

English: Rules can be checked in the <compBook>.
French: Tu peux consulter les règles dans le <compBook>.
Japanese: ルールは<compBook>で確認できる。
Portuguese: As regras podem ser consultadas no <compBook>.

English: Also have fun from <NPCName>.
French: Et amuse-toi de la part de <NPCName>.
Japanese: <NPCName>からも、お楽しみをとのことだ。

English: Nevermind.
French: Tant pis.

English: Once your signed up and the competition has started, catch as many bugs as you can.
French: Une fois que tu t'es inscrit(e) et que le concours a commencé, attrape autant d'insectes que possible.
Chinese (Simplified): 请先报名参赛，比赛开始之后，捕捉尽可能多的昆虫。
Japanese: 登録が済んで、大会が始まったら、できる限りたくさんの虫を捕まえるんだ。
Korean: 등록하고 대회가 시작되면 최대한 많은 버그를 잡아보세요.
Portuguese: Quando você se inscrever e a competição começar, pegue o máximo de insetos que conseguir.

English: The rarer the bug is, the more points it's worth.
French: Plus l'insecte est rare, plus il vaut de points.
Chinese (Simplified): 昆虫越稀有，其分数越高。
Japanese: 珍しい虫ほど、対応する獲得ポイントが増える。
Korean: 버그가 희귀할수록 더 많은 포인트를 얻을 수 있습니다.
Portuguese: Quanto mais raro o inseto, mais pontos vale.

English: The last score you enter into to the <compBook> will be your final score.
French: Le dernier score que tu enregistres dans le <compBook> sera ton score final.
Chinese (Simplified): 最后一次在<compBook>登记的分数即为最终分数。
Japanese: <compBook>に記録した最新のスコアが最終スコアになる。
Korean: <compBook>에 입력한 마지막 점수가 최종 점수가 됩니다.
Portuguese: A última pontuação que você inserir no <compBook> será sua pontuação final.

English: You can use the <compBook> to update your score at any time, as long as it's before <bugCompEndTime>.
French: Tu peux utiliser le <compBook> pour mettre à jour ton score à tout moment, avant <bugCompEndTime>.
Japanese: <bugCompEndTime>までは、<compBook>を使えばスコアをいつでも記録できる。
Korean: <bugCompEndTime> 이전이면 언제든지 <compBook>을 사용하여 점수를 업데이트할 수 있습니다.
Portuguese: Você pode usar o <compBook> para atualizar sua pontuação a qualquer momento, desde que seja antes de <bugCompEndTime>.

French: Merci pour ton inscription !

English: Please make sure you log your score in the <compBook> before the competition ends at <bugCompEndTime>.
French: N'oublie pas d'enregistrer ton score dans le <compBook> avant la fin du concours à <bugCompEndTime>.
Russian: Пожалуйста, не забудьте записать свой результат в <compBook> до окончания соревнования в <bugCompEndTime>.
Chinese (Simplified): 比赛将于<bugCompEndTime>结束，请务必在<compBook>登记你的分数。
Japanese: <compBook>の大会終了時間までに、忘れずにスコアを<bugCompEndTime>に記録してくれ。
Korean: 대회가 <bugCompEndTime>에 끝나기 전에 <compBook>에 점수를 기록했는지 확인하세요.
Portuguese: Certifique-se de registrar sua pontuação no <compBook> antes do fim da competição às <bugCompEndTime>.

English: Once you have signed up and the competition has started, catch as many <itemName> as you can.
French: Une fois que tu t'es inscrit(e) et que le concours a commencé, attrape autant de <itemName> que possible.
Russian: После того, как вы зарегистрируетесь и начнется соревнование, поймайте как можно больше <itemName>.
Chinese (Simplified): 请先报名参赛，比赛开始之后，捕捉尽可能多的<itemName>。
Japanese: 登録が済んで、大会が始まったら、できる限りたくさんの<itemName>を捕まえるんだ。
Korean: 등록하고 대회가 시작되면 <itemName>을 최대한 많이 잡으세요.
Portuguese: Quando você tiver se inscrito e a competição começar, pegue o máximo de <itemName> que conseguir.

English: Each <itemName> is worth 1 point.
French: Chaque <itemName> vaut 1 point.
Russian: Каждый <itemName> приносит 1 очко.

English: The last score you enter into the <compBook> will be your final score.
French: Le dernier score que tu enregistres dans le <compBook> sera ton score final.
Russian: Последний балл, который вы введете в <compBook>, будет вашим окончательным результатом.
Chinese (Simplified): 最后一次在<compBook>登记的分数即为最终分数。
Japanese: <compBook>に記録した最新のスコアが最終スコアになる。
Korean: <compBook>에 마지막으로 입력한 점수가 최종 점수가 됩니다.
Portuguese: A última pontuação que você inserir no <compBook> será sua pontuação final.
